events.title: The Chaotic Caucus-Race and Universal Prizes
detailed_summary: The Dodo sets up the race by drawing a roughly circular course and placing the participants haphazardly around it.
There is no formal start; participants begin and stop running whenever they wish, making the race's conclusion unclear.
After approximately half an hour, by which time everyone has dried off, the Dodo abruptly announces the end of the race.
The participants gather around the Dodo, eagerly asking who the winner is.
The Dodo requires significant time for thought, striking a contemplative pose, while the others wait silently.
Finally, the Dodo declares that everyone has won and, consequently, all must receive prizes.
A chorus of voices asks who will provide these prizes.
The Dodo points to Alice, designating her as the prize-giver.
Confused but prompted by the expectant crowd calling for 'Prizes!', Alice impulsively checks her pocket.
She finds a box of comfits (unharmed by the water) and distributes them, ensuring each participant receives exactly one.
The Mouse observes that Alice herself should receive a prize.
The Dodo agrees gravely and asks Alice what else she has in her pocket.
Alice sadly reveals she only has a thimble.
The Dodo instructs her to hand it over.
The group crowds around Alice again as the Dodo formally presents the thimble back to her as a prize, making a short, solemn speech of presentation, followed by cheers.
Alice perceives the entire event as ridiculous but refrains from laughing due to the serious demeanor of the others; unable to think of a response, she bows solemnly and accepts the thimble.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, (“the exact shape doesn’t matter,” it said,) and then all the party were placed along the course, here and there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Alice thought the whole thing very absurd, but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh; and, as she could not think of anything to say, she simply bowed, and took the thimble, looking as solemn as she could.

events.text_segment:
First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, (“the exact shape doesn’t matter,” it said,) and then all the party were placed along the course, here and there. There was no “One, two, three, and away,” but they began running when they liked, and left off when they liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over. However, when they had been running half an hour or so, and were quite dry again, the Dodo suddenly called out “The race is over!” and they all crowded round it, panting, and asking, “But who has won?”
This question the Dodo could not answer without a great deal of thought, and it sat for a long time with one finger pressed upon its forehead (the position in which you usually see Shakespeare, in the pictures of him), while the rest waited in silence. At last the Dodo said, “Everybody has won, and all must have prizes.”
“But who is to give the prizes?” quite a chorus of voices asked.
“Why, she, of course,” said the Dodo, pointing to Alice with one finger; and the whole party at once crowded round her, calling out in a confused way, “Prizes! Prizes!”
Alice had no idea what to do, and in despair she put her hand in her pocket, and pulled out a box of comfits, (luckily the salt water had not got into it), and handed them round as prizes. There was exactly one a-piece, all round.
“But she must have a prize herself, you know,” said the Mouse.
“Of course,” the Dodo replied very gravely. “What else have you got in your pocket?” he went on, turning to Alice.
“Only a thimble,” said Alice sadly.
“Hand it over here,” said the Dodo.
Then they all crowded round her once more, while the Dodo solemnly presented the thimble, saying “We beg your acceptance of this elegant thimble;” and, when it had finished this short speech, they all cheered.
Alice thought the whole thing very absurd, but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh; and, as she could not think of anything to say, she simply bowed, and took the thimble, looking as solemn as she could.

events.title: The Mouse's Sad Tale and Offense Taken
detailed_summary: The distribution and consumption of the comfits lead to some minor chaos, with larger birds complaining about the taste and smaller ones choking.
Once the comfits are finished, the group settles back into a ring and requests another story from the Mouse.
Alice specifically asks the Mouse to recount its history and explain its dislike for 'C and D,' whispering the letters cautiously.
The Mouse sighs and declares its tale to be 'long and sad'.

Alice, observing the Mouse's physical tail, misunderstands the word 'tale' and wonders aloud why its tail would be called sad, continuing to puzzle over this literal interpretation as the Mouse speaks.
The Mouse begins reciting a story presented visually as a winding tail, about a character named Fury attempting to prosecute a mouse without judge or jury, ultimately condemning it to death.
The Mouse interrupts its story to accuse Alice sternly of not paying attention and asks what she is thinking about.
Alice humbly apologizes, guessing the Mouse had reached the 'fifth bend,' referring to the shape of the tale/tail.
The Mouse reacts angrily, denying it had reached a 'bend,' seemingly interpreting Alice's word as 'knot'.
Alice, ever helpful, misunderstands the Mouse's anger and offers to help 'undo' the perceived knot.
The Mouse declares it will do no such thing, stating Alice is insulting it with nonsense, and begins to walk away.
Alice pleads that she didn't intend to offend, remarking on the Mouse's sensitivity.
The Mouse merely growls in response.
Alice and the others call after it, asking it to return and finish the story, but the Mouse ignores them, shaking its head and walking away faster.
Once the Mouse is gone, the Lory expresses regret, and an old Crab starts to lecture its daughter.

events.text_segment:
The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back. However, it was over at last, and they sat down again in a ring, and begged the Mouse to tell them something more.
“You promised to tell me your history, you know,” said Alice, “and why it is you hate—C and D,” she added in a whisper, half afraid that it would be offended again.
“Mine is a long and a sad tale!” said the Mouse, turning to Alice, and sighing.
“It is a long tail, certainly,” said Alice, looking down with wonder at the Mouse’s tail; “but why do you call it sad?” And she kept on puzzling about it while the Mouse was speaking, so that her idea of the tale was something like this:—
 “Fury said to a
         mouse, That he
        met in the
       house,
     ‘Let us
      both go to
       law: I will
        prosecute
         you.—Come,
           I’ll take no
           denial; We
          must have a
        trial: For
      really this
     morning I’ve
    nothing
    to do.’
      Said the
      mouse to the
       cur, ‘Such
        a trial,
         dear sir,
            With
          no jury
        or judge,
       would be
      wasting
      our
      breath.’
        ‘I’ll be
        judge, I’ll
         be jury,’
             Said
         cunning
          old Fury:
          ‘I’ll
          try the
            whole
            cause,
              and
           condemn
           you
          to
           death.’”
“You are not attending!” said the Mouse to Alice severely. “What are you thinking of?”
“I beg your pardon,” said Alice very humbly: “you had got to the fifth bend, I think?”
“I had not!” cried the Mouse, sharply and very angrily.
“A knot!” said Alice, always ready to make herself useful, and looking anxiously about her. “Oh, do let me help to undo it!”
“I shall do nothing of the sort,” said the Mouse, getting up and walking away. “You insult me by talking such nonsense!”
“I didn’t mean it!” pleaded poor Alice. “But you’re so easily offended, you know!”
The Mouse only growled in reply.
“Please come back and finish your story!” Alice called after it; and the others all joined in chorus, “Yes, please do!” but the Mouse only shook its head impatiently, and walked a little quicker.
“What a pity it wouldn’t stay!” sighed the Lory, as soon as it was quite out of sight; and an old Crab took the opportunity of saying to her daughter “Ah, my dear!

```plaintext
CHAPTER III. A Caucus-Race and a Long Tale

The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back. After the comfits were finished, the group settled back into a ring, and the Mouse was asked to tell its story. Alice, eager for entertainment, pressed the Mouse to recount its history and explain its dislike for 'C and D,' whispering the letters cautiously. The Mouse sighed and declared its tale to be 'long and sad.' Observing the Mouse's tail, Alice misunderstood the word 'tale' and wondered aloud why its tail would be called sad, continuing to puzzle over this literal interpretation as the Mouse began speaking.

The Mouse recited a story, visually presented as a winding tail, about Fury, a character who tried to prosecute a mouse without judge or jury, ultimately condemning it to death. Midway, the Mouse interrupted itself to scold Alice for not paying attention and asked what she was thinking about. Alice, apologizing humbly, guessed that the Mouse had reached the 'fifth bend,' referring to the shape of the tale/tail. The Mouse, angry, denied reaching a 'bend,' interpreting Alice's word as 'knot.' Misunderstanding, Alice offered to help 'undo' the perceived knot, but the Mouse declared it would do no such thing, insulted by Alice's nonsense, and began to walk away.

Alice pleaded, expressing that she meant no offense, noting the Mouse's sensitivity. The Mouse merely growled in response. Despite calls from Alice and others asking it to return and finish the story, the Mouse ignored them, shaking its head and walking away faster. Once the Mouse was gone, the Lory expressed regret, and an old Crab started to lecture its daughter, as the scene closed with the group reflecting on the strange encounter.
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Alice was just beginning to think that she might never get her turn when a sudden hush fell over the garden. The Queen of Hearts, with her stern face and commanding voice, called out, "Off with her head!" Alice looked around, startled, not understanding what she had done wrong. The Queen's courtiers hurried forward, but Alice, feeling quite overwhelmed, tried to explain that she hadn't meant any harm.

Meanwhile, the Cheshire Cat grinned from a nearby tree, his head slowly fading into a smile. "You're in a curious place," he said, his voice echoing softly. "Things are not always what they seem here."

Alice, feeling a bit more brave, asked, "What am I supposed to do?"

"Follow the White Rabbit," the Cat replied, "and perhaps you'll find your way out of this madness."

Suddenly, the White Rabbit dashed past, looking at his pocket watch and muttering, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" Alice hurried after him, her curiosity piqued. She found herself in a long hall with many locked doors. On a small table, she saw a key and a bottle labeled "Drink Me." Carefully, she took a sip, and immediately, she began to shrink.

Now tiny enough to pass through the keyhole, Alice entered a mysterious garden filled with strange flowers and peculiar creatures. She saw a caterpillar sitting on a mushroom, smoking a hookah.

"Who are you?" Alice asked.

"I am but a caterpillar," he replied, "and I am pondering the meaning of life."

Alice, feeling more confident, decided to explore further. She noticed a Cheshire Cat grinning from ear to ear, its body slowly fading into the trees.

As she wandered, she realized that in Wonderland, nothing was quite as it seemed, and she would need to be clever and brave to find her way home.

events.title: Alice's Cat Dinah Scares the Party Away
detailed_summary: The old Crab's attempt to teach her daughter a lesson about temper is immediately rebuffed by the young Crab telling her mother to be quiet.
Alice interjects loudly, wishing her cat Dinah were present, certain Dinah could retrieve the departed Mouse.
The Lory politely inquires about Dinah's identity.
Alice eagerly explains that Dinah is her pet cat.
She enthusiastically describes Dinah's prowess as a hunter, particularly her skill in catching mice and her tendency to eat birds instantly upon seeing them.
This description provokes significant alarm throughout the gathered party.
Some birds immediately hurry away.
An old Magpie begins preparing to leave, citing the unsuitability of the night air for its throat.
A Canary nervously calls its children to come away, stating it's past their bedtime.
Making various excuses, all the remaining members of the party depart, leaving Alice completely alone.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Let this be a lesson to you never to lose your temper!” “Hold your tongue, Ma!” said the young Crab, a little snappishly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On various pretexts they all moved off, and Alice was soon left alone.

events.text_segment:
Let this be a lesson to you never to lose your temper!” “Hold your tongue, Ma!” said the young Crab, a little snappishly. “You’re enough to try the patience of an oyster!”
“I wish I had our Dinah here, I know I do!” said Alice aloud, addressing nobody in particular. “She’d soon fetch it back!”
“And who is Dinah, if I might venture to ask the question?” said the Lory.
Alice replied eagerly, for she was always ready to talk about her pet: “Dinah’s our cat. And she’s such a capital one for catching mice you can’t think! And oh, I wish you could see her after the birds! Why, she’ll eat a little bird as soon as look at it!”
This speech caused a remarkable sensation among the party. Some of the birds hurried off at once: one old Magpie began wrapping itself up very carefully, remarking, “I really must be getting home; the night-air doesn’t suit my throat!” and a Canary called out in a trembling voice to its children, “Come away, my dears! It’s high time you were all in bed!” On various pretexts they all moved off, and Alice was soon left alone.

events.title: Solitude, Regret, and Hopeful Footsteps
detailed_summary: Left alone, Alice expresses regret to herself for having mentioned Dinah, realizing her cat is unpopular in this strange place.
She laments that despite Dinah being the best cat in the world, nobody down here seems to like her.
Alice voices longing for Dinah and wonders with sadness if she will ever see her again.
Feeling very lonely and low-spirited as a result, Alice begins to cry once more.
Shortly after, her crying subsides as she detects the faint sound of approaching footsteps.
She looks up with renewed eagerness, entertaining the hope that the Mouse might have reconsidered and is returning to finish its story.

events.text_segment: “I wish I hadn’t mentioned Dinah!” she said to herself in a melancholy tone. “Nobody seems to like her, down here, and I’m sure she’s the best cat in the world! Oh, my dear Dinah! I wonder if I shall ever see you any more!” And here poor Alice began to cry again, for she felt very lonely and low-spirited. In a little while, however, she again heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she looked up eagerly, half hoping that the Mouse had changed his mind, and was coming back to finish his story.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER IV. The Rabbit Sends in a Little Bill

events.title: The White Rabbit's Return and Mistaken Identity
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit reappeared, moving slowly and searching frantically.
He muttered anxiously about the Duchess, potential execution, and losing items Alice recognized as his fan and gloves.
Alice, observing the changed surroundings where the hall and table had disappeared, kindly started searching for the lost items.
The Rabbit spotted Alice and angrily mistook her for someone named Mary Ann.
He ordered her to go home immediately and bring him gloves and a fan.
Alice, startled and scared by his tone, obeyed instantly and ran in the direction he indicated, without correcting his mistake.
As she ran, Alice realized the Rabbit thought she was his servant.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “He took me for his housemaid,” she said to herself as she ran.

events.text_segment:
It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something; and she heard it muttering to itself “The Duchess! The Duchess! Oh my dear paws! Oh my fur and whiskers! She’ll get me executed, as sure as ferrets are ferrets! Where can I have dropped them, I wonder?” Alice guessed in a moment that it was looking for the fan and the pair of white kid gloves, and she very good-naturedly began hunting about for them, but they were nowhere to be seen—everything seemed to have changed since her swim in the pool, and the great hall, with the glass table and the little door, had vanished completely.
Very soon the Rabbit noticed Alice, as she went hunting about, and called out to her in an angry tone, “Why, Mary Ann, what are you doing out here? Run home this moment, and fetch me a pair of gloves and a fan! Quick, now!” And Alice was so much frightened that she ran off at once in the direction it pointed to, without trying to explain the mistake it had made.
“He took me for his housemaid,” she said to herself as she ran.

Alice's adventure was just beginning, and she was eager to discover what lay ahead.

events.title: Alice Enters the Rabbit's House and Drinks a Potion
detailed_summary: Alice considered the Rabbit's surprise upon discovering her true identity but resolved to fetch the fan and gloves if possible.
She arrived at a small, tidy house marked with a brass plate reading "W. RABBIT".
She entered without knocking and rushed upstairs, anxious to avoid encountering the actual Mary Ann.
Alice mused on the absurdity of running errands for a rabbit, comparing it to her cat Dinah potentially giving her orders.
She imagined a scenario where Dinah would boss her around, but concluded Dinah wouldn't be allowed to stay if she behaved that way.
Alice located a neat room with a table holding a fan and several pairs of small white kid gloves.
After picking up the fan and one pair of gloves, she noticed an unlabeled bottle near the mirror.
Despite the lack of instructions, she decided to drink from it, anticipating an interesting outcome based on her past experiences with Wonderland food and drinks.
She hoped the drink would restore her to a larger size, expressing weariness with being so small.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “How surprised he’ll be when he finds out who I am! But I’d better take him his fan and gloves—that is, if I can find them.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I do hope it’ll make me grow large again, for really I’m quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!”

events.text_segment:
“How surprised he’ll be when he finds out who I am! But I’d better take him his fan and gloves—that is, if I can find them.” As she said this, she came upon a neat little house, on the door of which was a bright brass plate with the name “W. RABBIT,” engraved upon it. She went in without knocking, and hurried upstairs, in great fear lest she should meet the real Mary Ann, and be turned out of the house before she had found the fan and gloves.
“How queer it seems,” Alice said to herself, “to be going messages for a rabbit! I suppose Dinah’ll be sending me on messages next!” And she began fancying the sort of thing that would happen: “‘Miss Alice! Come here directly, and get ready for your walk!’ ‘Coming in a minute, nurse! But I’ve got to see that the mouse doesn’t get out.’ Only I don’t think,” Alice went on, “that they’d let Dinah stop in the house if it began ordering people about like that!”
By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table in the window, and on it (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves: she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves, and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a little bottle that stood near the looking-glass. There was no label this time with the words “DRINK ME,” but nevertheless she uncorked it and put it to her lips. “I know something interesting is sure to happen,” she said to herself, “whenever I eat or drink anything; so I’ll just see what this bottle does. I do hope it’ll make me grow large again, for really I’m quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!”

events.title: Alice Grows Enormously and Becomes Trapped
detailed_summary: The drink worked rapidly; before finishing half, Alice's head hit the ceiling, forcing her to bend down.
She quickly put the bottle down, realizing she had had enough and hoping not to grow further.
She recognized she was already too large to exit through the door and regretted drinking so much.
Her regret came too late as she continued expanding.
Soon she had to kneel, and shortly after, even kneeling wasn't possible.
She tried lying down, positioning one elbow against the door and curling her other arm around her head.
Still growing, she resorted to putting one arm out the window and one foot up the chimney.
Feeling she could do nothing more, she wondered anxiously about her fate.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What will become of me?”

events.text_segment:
It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken. She hastily put down the bottle, saying to herself “That’s quite enough—I hope I shan’t grow any more—As it is, I can’t get out at the door—I do wish I hadn’t drunk quite so much!”
Alas! it was too late to wish that! She went on growing, and growing, and very soon had to kneel down on the floor: in another minute there was not even room for this, and she tried the effect of lying down with one elbow against the door, and the other arm curled round her head. Still she went on growing, and, as a last resource, she put one arm out of the window, and one foot up the chimney, and said to herself “Now I can do no more, whatever happens. What will become of me?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken. She felt a violent little wind rush at her as she fell, and her body was so large that she could not get out of the door at all. She was quite glad she had been so quick about it, and she tried to get out of the window, but she found she could not, for her arms were too long. She was quite uncomfortable, and she wished she had not drunk so much.

She was quite glad she had been so quick about it, and she tried to get out of the window, but she found she could not, for her arms were too long. She was quite uncomfortable, and she wished she had not drunk so much.

Soon she was too big to get out of the door, and she was sorry she had been so greedy. She tried to kneel down, but she was too big for that, and then she lay down on the floor, curling herself up as best she could. Still growing, she put one arm out of the window and one foot up the chimney, trying to find some way to stop herself from growing any larger. She was very anxious about her fate, and she wondered what would happen to her next.

events.title: Alice's Reflections While Trapped
detailed_summary: Fortunately, the bottle's effect ceased, stopping her growth, but her situation remained uncomfortable with no apparent escape, making her feel miserable.
Alice wistfully thought about home, where life was stable, unlike her current state of constant size changes and being bossed around by animals.
She momentarily regretted entering the rabbit-hole but acknowledged the curious nature of her adventures.
She marveled at finding herself within a real-life fairy tale, unlike the ones she read.
Alice felt her experiences were significant enough for a book and resolved to write one when she grew up, immediately realizing sadly that she was already fully grown within the confines of the room.
She contemplated the implications of potentially never aging further – a comfort in avoiding old age, but dreadful due to the prospect of perpetual lessons.
She then debated with herself, dismissing the idea of lessons due to the lack of space for herself, let alone books.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Why, there’s hardly room for you, and no room at all for any lesson-books!”

events.text_segment:
Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy.
“It was much pleasanter at home,” thought poor Alice, “when one wasn’t always growing larger and smaller, and being ordered about by mice and rabbits. I almost wish I hadn’t gone down that rabbit-hole—and yet—and yet—it’s rather curious, you know, this sort of life! I do wonder what can have happened to me! When I used to read fairy-tales, I fancied that kind of thing never happened, and now here I am in the middle of one! There ought to be a book written about me, that there ought! And when I grow up, I’ll write one—but I’m grown up now,” she added in a sorrowful tone; “at least there’s no room to grow up any more here.”
“But then,” thought Alice, “shall I never get any older than I am now? That’ll be a comfort, one way—never to be an old woman—but then—always to have lessons to learn! Oh, I shouldn’t like that!”
“Oh, you foolish Alice!” she answered herself. “How can you learn lessons in here? Why, there’s hardly room for you, and no room at all for any lesson-books!”

**CHAPTER IV. The Rabbit Sends in a Little Bill**

"Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy."

Fortunately, the bottle's effect ceased, stopping her growth, but her situation remained uncomfortable with no apparent escape, making her feel miserable. Alice wistfully thought about home, where life was stable, unlike her current state of constant size changes and being bossed around by animals. She thought to herself, "I wish I could get out of this room," but then she remembered how she had entered the rabbit-hole and felt a mixture of curiosity and regret. She marveled at finding herself within a real fairy tale, quite different from the stories she used to read. She even thought, "Perhaps I should write a book about all this when I grow up," but then she immediately realized, "Oh dear! I shall be too big for the room if I grow any more," and felt a little sad about that. 

She considered the idea of never growing any larger again, thinking, "It would be a comfort not to grow old," but then added, "It would be dreadful to be always learning lessons and never getting anywhere." She debated with herself, "But how can I learn lessons if there's no room for books or even for me to sit?" and dismissed the idea of lessons altogether, concluding, "There's no room for lessons or books, so I might as well give up on that." 

She then looked around and thought about her predicament, feeling both amused and anxious, and wondered what would happen next.

---

detailed_summary: Alice's internal debate was interrupted by a voice outside calling for "Mary Ann" and demanding gloves.
Hearing footsteps on the stairs, Alice identified the Rabbit approaching and trembled, momentarily forgetting her immense size advantage.
The Rabbit reached the door and tried to open it, but failed because it opened inward and Alice's elbow blocked it.
Alice overheard the Rabbit deciding to try entering through the window instead.
Alice silently resolved to prevent this.
Waiting until she thought the Rabbit was beneath the window, she quickly reached her hand out, snatching at the air.
Though she caught nothing, she heard a cry, a fall, and breaking glass, guessing the Rabbit might have fallen into a cucumber-frame.
The Rabbit's angry voice then called for someone named Pat.
Another voice, new to Alice, responded, claiming to be digging for apples.
The Rabbit angrily dismissed this and ordered Pat to help him out, accompanied by more sounds of broken glass.
The Rabbit asked Pat what was visible in the window.
Pat identified it as an arm, despite its unusual size filling the entire window.
The Rabbit, calling Pat a goose, declared the arm had no right to be there and ordered Pat to remove it.

events.text_segment:
And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside, and stopped to listen.
“Mary Ann! Mary Ann!” said the voice. “Fetch me my gloves this moment!” Then came a little pattering of feet on the stairs. Alice knew it was the Rabbit coming to look for her, and she trembled till she shook the house, quite forgetting that she was now about a thousand times as large as the Rabbit, and had no reason to be afraid of it.
Presently the Rabbit came up to the door, and tried to open it; but, as the door opened inwards, and Alice’s elbow was pressed hard against it, that attempt proved a failure. Alice heard it say to itself “Then I’ll go round and get in at the window.”
“That you won’t!” thought Alice, and, after waiting till she fancied she heard the Rabbit just under the window, she suddenly spread out her hand, and made a snatch in the air. She did not get hold of anything, but she heard a little shriek and a fall, and a crash of broken glass, from which she concluded that it was just possible it had fallen into a cucumber-frame, or something of the sort.
Next came an angry voice—the Rabbit’s—“Pat! Pat! Where are you?” And then a voice she had never heard before, “Sure then I’m here! Digging for apples, yer honour!”
“Digging for apples, indeed!” said the Rabbit angrily. “Here! Come and help me out of this!” (Sounds of more broken glass.)
“Now tell me, Pat, what’s that in the window?”
“Sure, it’s an arm, yer honour!” (He pronounced it “arrum.”)
“An arm, you goose! Who ever saw one that size? Why, it fills the whole window!”
“Sure, it does, yer honour: but it’s an arm for all that.”
“Well, it’s got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!”

events.title: Bill the Lizard's Chimney Descent and Expulsion
detailed_summary: Following a silence punctuated by whispers indicating Pat's reluctance and the Rabbit's insistence, Alice made another snatching motion with her hand.
This resulted in two small shrieks and more glass breaking sounds, leading Alice to wonder about the abundance of cucumber-frames.
She hoped they could pull her out, as she wished to leave the room.
After a period of quiet, Alice heard cartwheels and many voices conferring.
She deciphered fragments of conversation about ladders, ropes, roof stability, falling slates, and assigning blame to someone named Bill.
The discussion concluded with the decision that Bill must go down the chimney.
Alice noted internally that Bill seemed to be assigned all the difficult tasks.
Considering Bill's likely predicament in the narrow fireplace, Alice prepared herself, thinking she could deliver a kick.

events.text_segment:
There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then; such as, “Sure, I don’t like it, yer honour, at all, at all!” “Do as I tell you, you coward!” and at last she spread out her hand again, and made another snatch in the air. This time there were two little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass. “What a number of cucumber-frames there must be!” thought Alice. “I wonder what they’ll do next! As for pulling me out of the window, I only wish they could! I’m sure I don’t want to stay in here any longer!”
She waited for some time without hearing anything more: at last came a rumbling of little cartwheels, and the sound of a good many voices all talking together: she made out the words: “Where’s the other ladder?—Why, I hadn’t to bring but one; Bill’s got the other—Bill! fetch it here, lad!—Here, put ’em up at this corner—No, tie ’em together first—they don’t reach half high enough yet—Oh! they’ll do well enough; don’t be particular—Here, Bill! catch hold of this rope—Will the roof bear?—Mind that loose slate—Oh, it’s coming down! Heads below!” (a loud crash)—“Now, who did that?—It was Bill, I fancy—Who’s to go down the chimney?—Nay, I shan’t! You do it!—That I won’t, then!—Bill’s to go down—Here, Bill! the master says you’re to go down the chimney!”
“Oh! So Bill’s got to come down the chimney, has he?” said Alice to herself. “Shy, they seem to put everything upon Bill! I wouldn’t be in Bill’s place for a good deal: this fireplace is narrow, to be sure; but I think I can kick a little!”

events.title: Failed Expulsion, Pebble Attack, and Magical Cakes
detailed_summary: Alice positioned her foot in the chimney and waited.
Hearing a small animal scrambling above, she identified it as Bill and delivered a swift kick.
A collective shout of "There goes Bill!" followed, along with the Rabbit urging others to catch him.
After a silence, confused voices were heard tending to Bill, asking what happened.
A weak, squeaky voice (identified by Alice as Bill's) responded, stating he felt better but too flustered to explain, only knowing something shot him up like a sky-rocket.
The others confirmed his description.
The Rabbit's voice then suggested burning the house down.
Alice loudly threatened to send her cat Dinah after them if they did.
An immediate silence fell; Alice wondered about their next move, thinking removing the roof would be more sensible.
After a pause, movement resumed, and Alice heard the Rabbit order a barrowful of something.
Alice wondered what it could be, but soon a shower of small pebbles rained in through the window, some hitting her face.
She resolved to stop this and shouted a warning, causing another silence.
Alice noticed the pebbles on the floor were transforming into tiny cakes.
This sparked an idea: eating a cake would likely alter her size, and since she couldn't get larger, it must make her smaller.

events.text_segment:
She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited till she heard a little animal (she couldn’t guess of what sort it was) scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then, saying to herself “This is Bill,” she gave one sharp kick, and waited to see what would happen next.
The first thing she heard was a general chorus of “There goes Bill!” then the Rabbit’s voice along—“Catch him, you by the hedge!” then silence, and then another confusion of voices—“Hold up his head—Brandy now—Don’t choke him—How was it, old fellow? What happened to you? Tell us all about it!”
Last came a little feeble, squeaking voice, (“That’s Bill,” thought Alice,) “Well, I hardly know—No more, thank ye; I’m better now—but I’m a deal too flustered to tell you—all I know is, something comes at me like a Jack-in-the-box, and up I goes like a sky-rocket!”
“So you did, old fellow!” said the others.
“We must burn the house down!” said the Rabbit’s voice; and Alice called out as loud as she could, “If you do, I’ll set Dinah at you!”
There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, “I wonder what they will do next! If they had any sense, they’d take the roof off.” After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and Alice heard the Rabbit say, “A barrowful will do, to begin with.”
“A barrowful of what?” thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt, for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the window, and some of them hit her in the face. “I’ll put a stop to this,” she said to herself, and shouted out, “You’d better not do that again!” which produced another dead silence.
Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her head. “If I eat one of these cakes,” she thought, “it’s sure to make some change in my size; and as it can’t possibly make me larger, it must make me smaller, I suppose.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Sure enough, the moment she kicked, a little creature tumbled down into the fireplace, tumbling over and over, and finally landing with a soft thump on the hearth. Alice peered down, curious to see what it was, but the creature was so small and furry that she could hardly make it out. It had a long tail and tiny paws, and it looked up at her with bright, inquisitive eyes.

"Oh!" Alice exclaimed, leaning closer. "Are you Bill?"

The creature twitched its nose and nodded, then looked around nervously. Alice was about to speak again when she noticed that the creature was wearing a tiny waistcoat and a little hat, which seemed quite out of place for a creature so small.

"Well, Bill," she said softly, "what are you doing up in the chimney?"

Bill looked at her with a mixture of surprise and relief. "I was just trying to get out of the way of the Queen's soldiers," he explained hurriedly. "They've been searching everywhere for me."

Alice's eyes widened. "The Queen's soldiers? What have you done?"

"Nothing much," Bill replied, shrugging. "Just a little misunderstanding about some flowers in the garden."

Alice nodded sympathetically, then looked around the fireplace. It was dark and sooty, but she could see that Bill was quite a clever little animal. She wondered if she should help him escape.

"Hold on," she said, reaching out her hand. "I'll help you get out of here."

Bill hesitated for a moment, then scampered onto her hand. Alice carefully lifted him up, feeling a strange sense of responsibility for her new tiny friend. As she looked at him, she thought about the strange and wonderful adventures that awaited her in Wonderland.

events.title: Shrinking, Escape, and a New Plan
detailed_summary: Alice consumed one of the small cakes and was pleased to feel herself shrinking immediately.
Once small enough to fit through the doorway, she dashed out of the house.
Outside, she encountered a crowd of small animals and birds.
Bill the Lizard was present, looking unwell and supported by two guinea-pigs administering something from a bottle.
The assembled creatures rushed towards Alice upon her appearance.
She fled quickly, soon reaching the safety of a dense wood.
Wandering in the wood, Alice decided on a two-part plan: first, regain her normal height, and second, find her way to the beautiful garden she had seen earlier.

events.text_segment:
So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she began shrinking directly. As soon as she was small enough to get through the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little animals and birds waiting outside. The poor little Lizard, Bill, was in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it something out of a bottle. They all made a rush at Alice the moment she appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself safe in a thick wood.
“The first thing I’ve got to do,” said Alice to herself, as she wandered about in the wood, “is to grow to my right size again; and the second thing is to find my way into that lovely garden. I think that will be the best plan.”

events.title: Encounter with the Giant Puppy
detailed_summary: Alice acknowledged her plan sounded good but lacked specifics on execution.
While searching among the trees, a sharp bark startled her into looking up.
An enormous puppy with large eyes looked down at her, tentatively reaching out a paw.
Alice spoke to it gently, calling it a poor thing and attempting to whistle, though she felt terrified it might be hungry and eat her.
Almost automatically, she picked up a small stick and offered it to the puppy.
The puppy leaped excitedly, yelped with joy, and playfully attacked the stick.
Alice hid behind a large thistle to avoid being trampled.
When she reappeared, the puppy rushed the stick again, tumbling in its eagerness.
Comparing the interaction to playing with a huge cart-horse, Alice dodged around the thistle again, anticipating being run over.
The puppy then began making short dashes at the stick, retreating further each time, barking hoarsely.
Eventually, it sat down far off, panting, with its tongue out and eyes half-closed.
Alice seized this chance to escape, running until exhausted and the puppy's barks faded.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a great hurry.

events.text_segment:
It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a great hurry.
An enormous puppy was looking down at her with large round eyes, and feebly stretching out one paw, trying to touch her. “Poor little thing!” said Alice, in a coaxing tone, and she tried hard to whistle to it; but she was terribly frightened all the time at the thought that it might be hungry, in which case it would be very likely to eat her up in spite of all her coaxing.
Hardly knowing what she did, she picked up a little bit of stick, and held it out to the puppy; whereupon the puppy jumped into the air off all its feet at once, with a yelp of delight, and rushed at the stick, and made believe to worry it; then Alice dodged behind a great thistle, to keep herself from being run over; and the moment she appeared on the other side, the puppy made another rush at the stick, and tumbled head over heels in its hurry to get hold of it; then Alice, thinking it was very like having a game of play with a cart-horse, and expecting every moment to be trampled under its feet, ran round the thistle again; then the puppy began a series of short charges at the stick, running a very little way forwards each time and a long way back, and barking hoarsely all the while, till at last it sat down a good way off, panting, with its tongue hanging out of its mouth, and its great eyes half shut.
This seemed to Alice a good opportunity for making her escape; so she set off at once, and ran till she was quite tired and out of breath, and till the puppy’s bark sounded quite faint in the distance.

It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a great hurry.

Looking up, Alice saw an enormous puppy with large, gentle eyes, gazing down at her. It reached out a paw tentatively, and Alice, feeling a mixture of curiosity and fear, spoke softly to it, calling it a poor thing and trying to whistle, though she was quite frightened it might be hungry and might eat her.

Almost automatically, she picked up a small stick and offered it to the puppy. The puppy leaped excitedly, yelped with joy, and playfully attacked the stick. Alice quickly hid behind a large thistle to avoid being trampled.

When she reappeared, the puppy dashed at the stick again, tumbling in its eagerness. Alice dodged around the thistle, expecting to be run over, as the puppy played with the stick like a huge cart-horse.

The puppy then began making short dashes at the stick, retreating further each time, barking hoarsely. Eventually, it sat down far off, panting, with its tongue hanging out and eyes half-closed.

Seizing this opportunity, Alice ran away until she was exhausted, and the puppy's barks faded into the distance.

events.title: Reflection and Discovery of the Caterpillar
detailed_summary: Resting against a buttercup and using a leaf as a fan, Alice fondly recalled the puppy, wishing she had been the right size to train it.
This reminded her of the urgent need to grow back to her normal size.
She pondered how to achieve this, recognizing she likely needed to eat or drink something, but unsure what.
The question of 'what' seemed paramount.
Alice surveyed the surrounding flowers and grass but saw nothing suitable.
Nearby, she noticed a large mushroom, roughly her current height.
After examining its sides and underneath, she decided to check its top.
Stretching onto her toes, she looked over the mushroom's edge.
Her gaze met that of a large, blue caterpillar sitting atop the mushroom.
The caterpillar had its arms folded, was calmly smoking a hookah, and paid no attention to Alice or its surroundings.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large blue caterpillar, that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly smoking a long hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else.

events.text_segment:
“And yet what a dear little puppy it was!” said Alice, as she leant against a buttercup to rest herself, and fanned herself with one of the leaves: “I should have liked teaching it tricks very much, if—if I’d only been the right size to do it! Oh dear! I’d nearly forgotten that I’ve got to grow up again! Let me see—how is it to be managed? I suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other; but the great question is, what?”
The great question certainly was, what? Alice looked all round her at the flowers and the blades of grass, but she did not see anything that looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances. There was a large mushroom growing near her, about the same height as herself; and when she had looked under it, and on both sides of it, and behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what was on the top of it.
She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large blue caterpillar, that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly smoking a long hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER V. Advice from a Caterpillar

events.title: An Unsettling Conversation About Identity
detailed_summary: Alice and the Caterpillar observe each other silently until the Caterpillar, removing its hookah, speaks in a tired tone.
The Caterpillar bluntly asks Alice for her identity.
Alice finds this an awkward start and shyly explains she barely knows herself at the moment, feeling she has changed multiple times since morning.
The Caterpillar sternly demands she clarify her statement.
Alice expresses her inability to explain, stating she isn't herself.
The Caterpillar dismisses her explanation, claiming not to understand.
Alice politely reiterates her confusion, noting the difficulty of understanding it herself and the disorienting effect of constantly changing size.
The Caterpillar denies that changing size is confusing.
Alice suggests the Caterpillar might feel differently when it undergoes its own transformation into a butterfly.
The Caterpillar remains dismissive of the idea.
Alice concedes their feelings might differ, but insists the experience would be strange for her.
The Caterpillar repeats its question, "Who are you?", with contempt.
Frustrated by the Caterpillar's brief replies and the circular conversation, Alice stands taller and insists the Caterpillar should identify itself first.
The Caterpillar simply asks why.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence: at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth, and addressed her in a languid, sleepy voice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Why?” said the Caterpillar.

events.text_segment:
The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence: at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth, and addressed her in a languid, sleepy voice.
“Who are you?” said the Caterpillar.
This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied, rather shyly, “I—I hardly know, sir, just at present—at least I know who I was when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then.”
“What do you mean by that?” said the Caterpillar sternly. “Explain yourself!”
“I can’t explain myself, I’m afraid, sir,” said Alice, “because I’m not myself, you see.”
“I don’t see,” said the Caterpillar.
“I’m afraid I can’t put it more clearly,” Alice replied very politely, “for I can’t understand it myself to begin with; and being so many different sizes in a day is very confusing.”
“It isn’t,” said the Caterpillar.
“Well, perhaps you haven’t found it so yet,” said Alice; “but when you have to turn into a chrysalis—you will some day, you know—and then after that into a butterfly, I should think you’ll feel it a little queer, won’t you?”
“Not a bit,” said the Caterpillar.
“Well, perhaps your feelings may be different,” said Alice; “all I know is, it would feel very queer to me.”
“You!” said the Caterpillar contemptuously. “Who are you?”
Which brought them back again to the beginning of the conversation. Alice felt a little irritated at the Caterpillar’s making such very short remarks, and she drew herself up and said, very gravely, “I think, you ought to tell me who you are, first.”
“Why?” said the Caterpillar.

events.title: Keeping Temper and Reciting Incorrectly
detailed_summary: Stumped by the Caterpillar's question and sensing its unpleasant mood, Alice decides to leave.
The Caterpillar calls her back, claiming to have something important to tell her.
Intrigued, Alice returns.
The Caterpillar advises her to control her temper.
Alice, suppressing her anger, asks if that's the only important message.
The Caterpillar confirms it is not.
Alice decides to wait, hoping for useful information.
After smoking its hookah silently for a while, the Caterpillar asks Alice if she truly believes she has changed.
Alice confirms her feeling of change, mentioning her inability to remember things correctly and her fluctuating size.
The Caterpillar probes further, asking what specific things she cannot remember.
Alice explains her failed attempt to recite "How doth the little busy bee," noting how the words came out incorrectly.
The Caterpillar instructs her to recite the poem "You are old, Father William."
Alice folds her hands and begins the recitation, detailing a conversation between a young man and Father William about his unusual habits despite his age.

The poem includes Father William's explanations for standing on his head, doing back-somersaults, eating a whole goose, and balancing an eel on his nose, culminating in him telling the youth to leave.
After Alice finishes, the Caterpillar declares that she did not recite it correctly.
Alice timidly agrees, admitting some words were altered.
The Caterpillar firmly states the recitation was entirely incorrect, leading to another pause in conversation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a very unpleasant state of mind, she turned away.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It is wrong from beginning to end,” said the Caterpillar decidedly, and there was silence for some minutes.

events.text_segment:
Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a very unpleasant state of mind, she turned away.
“Come back!” the Caterpillar called after her. “I’ve something important to say!”
This sounded promising, certainly: Alice turned and came back again.
“Keep your temper,” said the Caterpillar.
“Is that all?” said Alice, swallowing down her anger as well as she could.
“No,” said the Caterpillar.
Alice thought she might as well wait, as she had nothing else to do, and perhaps after all it might tell her something worth hearing. For some minutes it puffed away without speaking, but at last it unfolded its arms, took the hookah out of its mouth again, and said, “So you think you’re changed, do you?”
“I’m afraid I am, sir,” said Alice; “I can’t remember things as I used—and I don’t keep the same size for ten minutes together!”
“Can’t remember what things?” said the Caterpillar.
“Well, I’ve tried to say “How doth the little busy bee,” but it all came different!” Alice replied in a very melancholy voice.
“Repeat, “You are old, Father William,’” said the Caterpillar.
Alice folded her hands, and began:—
“You are old, Father William,” the young man said,
    “And your hair has become very white;
And yet you incessantly stand on your head—
    Do you think, at your age, it is right?”

“In my youth,” Father William replied to his son,
    “I feared it might injure the brain;
But, now that I’m perfectly sure I have none,
    Why, I do it again and again.”

“You are old,” said the youth, “as I mentioned before,
    And have grown most uncommonly fat;
Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door—
    Pray, what is the reason of that?”

“In my youth,” said the sage, as he shook his grey locks,
    “I kept all my limbs very supple
By the use of this ointment—one shilling the box—
    Allow me to sell you a couple?”

“You are old,” said the youth, “and your jaws are too weak
    For anything tougher than suet;
Yet you finished the goose, with the bones and the beak—
    Pray, how did you manage to do it?”

“In my youth,” said his father, “I took to the law,
    And argued each case with my wife;
And the muscular strength, which it gave to my jaw,
    Has lasted the rest of my life.”

“You are old,” said the youth, “one would hardly suppose
    That your eye was as steady as ever;
Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose—
    What made you so awfully clever?”

“I have answered three questions, and that is enough,”
    Said his father; “don’t give yourself airs!
Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff?
    Be off, or I’ll kick you down stairs!”
“That is not said right,” said the Caterpillar.
“Not quite right, I’m afraid,” said Alice, timidly; “some of the words have got altered.”
“It is wrong from beginning to end,” said the Caterpillar decidedly, and there was silence for some minutes.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a very unpleasant state of mind, she turned away.

The Caterpillar called after her, 'Come back and have some of this; I do believe it’s called a whiting.'

Alice looked around her for some way of escaping from the unpleasantness of the conversation, but it was of no use.

The Caterpillar, who was sitting on a mushroom, smoked his hookah and looked at her with a very serious expression.

'What size do you want to be?' he asked.

Alice was a little startled, but she answered, 'I should like to be a little larger, please.'

The Caterpillar nodded, and then he said, 'You’d better take a little more of this,' and he handed her a piece of mushroom.

Alice took a bite, and immediately she felt a strange sensation, as if she was growing larger.

She looked down at herself and saw that she was indeed growing, and she was quite pleased.

'That’s better,' she said, 'but I still feel a little small.'

The Caterpillar looked at her thoughtfully and said, 'You must learn to control your temper.'

Alice, suppressing her anger, asked, 'Is that the only important message you have for me?'

The Caterpillar nodded, 'No, it is not.'

Alice decided to wait, hoping for some useful information.

After smoking his hookah silently for a while, the Caterpillar asked Alice if she truly believed she had changed.

Alice confirmed her feeling of change, mentioning her inability to remember things correctly and her fluctuating size.

The Caterpillar probed further, asking what specific things she cannot remember.

Alice explained her failed attempt to recite 'How doth the little busy bee,' noting how the words came out incorrectly.

The Caterpillar then instructed her to recite the poem 'You are old, Father William.'

Alice folded her hands and began the recitation, describing a conversation between a young man and Father William about his unusual habits despite his age.

The poem included Father William's explanations for standing on his head, doing back-somersaults, eating a whole goose, and balancing an eel on his nose, culminating in him telling the youth to leave.

After Alice finished, the Caterpillar declared that she did not recite it correctly.

Alice timidly agreed, admitting some words were altered.

The Caterpillar firmly stated the recitation was entirely incorrect, leading to another pause in conversation.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Alice looked around, trying to find some way to make sense of the strange creature's words. The Caterpillar, sitting atop a mushroom and smoking a hookah, seemed lost in thought, its eyes half-closed and its voice slow and deliberate. Alice wondered what it could possibly mean by its cryptic advice, and whether she should trust it or not.

As she pondered, she noticed that the mushroom beneath her feet was unlike any she had seen before. It was bright red with white spots, and seemed to shimmer in the sunlight. Curious, she reached out and touched it, feeling a strange tingling sensation. Suddenly, she remembered the Caterpillar's words about eating a bit of the mushroom to change her size.

Thinking it might help her understand the strange world she was in, Alice carefully took a small piece of the mushroom and ate it. Instantly, she felt a strange sensation, as if she was shrinking down to a tiny size. She looked around and saw the world from a new perspective, much smaller than before.

As she continued to explore, Alice encountered more peculiar creatures and objects. There was a White Rabbit hurriedly checking his pocket watch, muttering about being late. There was a Mad Hatter's tea party, where the table was set with mismatched cups and saucers, and the guests were engaged in nonsensical conversations.

Alice joined the tea party, feeling both amused and bewildered. The Mad Hatter asked her riddles that had no answers, and the March Hare chuckled at the absurdity of it all. Despite the confusion, Alice enjoyed the whimsical atmosphere, though she longed to find her way back home.

Suddenly, she remembered the advice of the Caterpillar and decided to eat another piece of the mushroom to grow larger again. As she did so, she gradually increased in size, until she was back to her original height. She took a moment to compose herself, realizing that this strange land was full of surprises and lessons.

With renewed determination, Alice continued her journey, eager to discover more about this curious world. She encountered a Cheshire Cat, whose grin appeared and disappeared at will, and who offered cryptic guidance. Alice learned that sometimes, things are not what they seem, and that curiosity and courage are her best tools.

As she navigated through the Wonderland, Alice kept in mind the importance of staying true to herself, even amidst the chaos. She understood that the strange creatures and riddles were part of a larger story, one that she was meant to explore and understand.

Eventually, Alice found her way to a beautiful garden, filled with colorful flowers and singing birds. She felt a sense of peace and wonder, knowing that her adventures had taught her valuable lessons about imagination, bravery, and the importance of asking questions.

And so, Alice's journey in Wonderland continued, each day bringing new surprises and insights, as she learned to embrace the fantastical world around her and to trust in her own curiosity and sense of wonder.

events.title: Contradictions, Size Complaints, and Cryptic Advice
detailed_summary: Breaking the silence, the Caterpillar asks Alice what size she wishes to be.
Alice replies hastily that she isn't particular, but dislikes the frequent changes.
The Caterpillar contradicts her, stating it doesn't know about disliking changes.
Alice remains silent, feeling increasingly frustrated by the constant contradiction and struggling to maintain her composure.
The Caterpillar asks if she is content now.
Alice expresses a desire to be slightly larger, finding her current three-inch height wretched.
The Caterpillar, exactly three inches tall itself, angrily defends the height as excellent, rearing up as it speaks.
Alice pleads that she isn't accustomed to being so small and internally wishes creatures weren't so easily offended.
The Caterpillar tells her she will get used to it and resumes smoking.
Alice waits patiently for it to speak again.
After a few moments, the Caterpillar yawns, shakes itself, gets off the mushroom, and starts crawling away.
As it leaves, it casually remarks that one side will make her taller and the other shorter.
Alice wonders silently, "One side of what?"
The Caterpillar, seemingly reading her thoughts, specifies "Of the mushroom" before disappearing completely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Caterpillar was the first to speak.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Of the mushroom,” said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.

events.text_segment:
The Caterpillar was the first to speak.
“What size do you want to be?” it asked.
“Oh, I’m not particular as to size,” Alice hastily replied; “only one doesn’t like changing so often, you know.”
“I don’t know,” said the Caterpillar.
Alice said nothing: she had never been so much contradicted in her life before, and she felt that she was losing her temper.
“Are you content now?” said the Caterpillar.
“Well, I should like to be a little larger, sir, if you wouldn’t mind,” said Alice: “three inches is such a wretched height to be.”
“It is a very good height indeed!” said the Caterpillar angrily, rearing itself upright as it spoke (it was exactly three inches high).
“But I’m not used to it!” pleaded poor Alice in a piteous tone. And she thought of herself, “I wish the creatures wouldn’t be so easily offended!”
“You’ll get used to it in time,” said the Caterpillar; and it put the hookah into its mouth and began smoking again.
This time Alice waited patiently until it chose to speak again. In a minute or two the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth and yawned once or twice, and shook itself. Then it got down off the mushroom, and crawled away in the grass, merely remarking as it went, “One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you grow shorter.”
“One side of what? The other side of what?” thought Alice to herself.
“Of the mushroom,” said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.

Alice looked up, surprised to find a large caterpillar smoking a hookah, sitting atop a mushroom. 'I hardly know, sir, just at present,' Alice replied. 'At least I know who I was when I got up this morning,' she added, 'but I think I must have been changed several times since then.' The Caterpillar looked at her with a puzzled expression. 'What size do you wish to be?' it inquired. Alice hesitated, then said, 'Oh, I'm not particular, only I don't like changing so often.' The Caterpillar shook its head. 'I don't know about liking or disliking changes,' it said. Alice felt a bit annoyed at the contradiction but kept silent. The Caterpillar then asked, 'Are you content now?' Alice sighed and replied, 'I should like to be a little larger, sir, if you wouldn't mind.' The Caterpillar, who was exactly three inches high, looked at her with a frown. 'Three inches is a very good height,' it declared, rearing up as it spoke. Alice, feeling uncomfortable, wished she were a little taller and thought to herself that she was tired of being so small. The Caterpillar told her she would get used to it and resumed smoking. Alice waited patiently, watching it. After a moment, the Caterpillar yawned, shook itself, and began to crawl away from the mushroom. As it left, it casually remarked, 'One side will make you grow taller, and the other side shorter.' Alice wondered silently, 'One side of what?' The Caterpillar, seeming to read her thoughts, said, 'Of the mushroom,' and disappeared completely.

With renewed confidence, she took a deep breath and prepared to continue her adventure, eager to discover what lay ahead in this wondrous land.

events.title: Experimenting with the Mushroom's Effects
detailed_summary: Alice contemplates the round mushroom, finding it difficult to determine its two sides.
She stretches her arms around it and breaks off a piece from opposite edges with each hand.
Wondering which piece does what, she nibbles the right-hand bit.
Instantly, she feels a sharp blow under her chin as her foot strikes it.
Alarmed by this sudden and rapid shrinking, she realizes she must act quickly.
She immediately tries to eat the other piece.
Her chin is jammed against her foot, making it almost impossible to open her mouth, but she eventually succeeds in swallowing a piece of the left-hand bit.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her chin was pressed so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the lefthand bit.

events.text_segment:
Alice remained looking thoughtfully at the mushroom for a minute, trying to make out which were the two sides of it; and as it was perfectly round, she found this a very difficult question. However, at last she stretched her arms round it as far as they would go, and broke off a bit of the edge with each hand.
“And now which is which?” she said to herself, and nibbled a little of the right-hand bit to try the effect: the next moment she felt a violent blow underneath her chin: it had struck her foot!
She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change, but she felt that there was no time to be lost, as she was shrinking rapidly; so she set to work at once to eat some of the other bit. Her chin was pressed so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the lefthand bit.

events.title: Mistaken Identity: Alice and the Pigeon
detailed_summary: Alice feels relief as her head is freed, but this turns to alarm as she discovers her shoulders are gone, replaced by an enormously long neck stretching high above a canopy of leaves.
She wonders about the green expanse below and the location of her shoulders and hands, which she cannot see despite moving them.
Finding her hands unreachable, she discovers her neck is highly flexible, like a serpent's.
She successfully bends her neck down in a zigzag pattern towards the leaves, realizing they are treetops.
As she is about to explore the leaves, a large Pigeon flies into her face, hissing and beating her with its wings.
The Pigeon screams "Serpent!" at her.
Alice indignantly denies being a serpent and tells it to leave her alone.
The Pigeon insists she is a serpent, adding mournfully that nothing satisfies 'them' (serpents).
Alice professes confusion about the Pigeon's remarks.
The Pigeon continues its lament about searching for a safe place (roots, banks, hedges) away from serpents, ignoring Alice.
Alice becomes increasingly puzzled but waits for the Pigeon to finish.
The Pigeon complains about the difficulty of hatching eggs while constantly needing to watch for serpents, claiming it hasn't slept properly in weeks.
Alice, beginning to understand the Pigeon's perspective, expresses sympathy for its troubles.
The Pigeon shrieks about finding the tallest tree, only to have serpents (like Alice's head) appear from the sky.
Alice forcefully denies being a serpent, struggling to define what she is.
The Pigeon challenges her to state her identity, accusing her of inventing something.
Alice hesitantly identifies herself as a little girl, recalling her recent transformations.
The Pigeon dismisses this contemptuously, stating it has never seen a girl with such a long neck and insists she is a serpent, asking if she eats eggs.
Alice truthfully admits to eating eggs but argues little girls eat them too.
The Pigeon doesn't believe her and concludes that if girls eat eggs, they are simply another type of serpent.
This novel idea silences Alice, allowing the Pigeon to accuse her of searching for its eggs and claiming her identity (girl or serpent) doesn't matter to it.
Alice hastily retorts that her identity matters greatly to her, denies seeking eggs, and adds she wouldn't want the Pigeon's raw eggs anyway.
The Pigeon sulkily tells her to leave and settles back into its nest.

events.text_segment:
“Come, my head’s free at last!” said Alice in a tone of delight, which changed into alarm in another moment, when she found that her shoulders were nowhere to be found: all she could see, when she looked down, was an immense length of neck, which seemed to rise like a stalk out of a sea of green leaves that lay far below her.
“What can all that green stuff be?” said Alice. “And where have my shoulders got to? And oh, my poor hands, how is it I can’t see you?” She was moving them about as she spoke, but no result seemed to follow, except a little shaking among the distant green leaves.
As there seemed to be no chance of getting her hands up to her head, she tried to get her head down to them, and was delighted to find that her neck would bend about easily in any direction, like a serpent. She had just succeeded in curving it down into a graceful zigzag, and was going to dive in among the leaves, which she found to be nothing but the tops of the trees under which she had been wandering, when a sharp hiss made her draw back in a hurry: a large pigeon had flown into her face, and was beating her violently with its wings.
“Serpent!” screamed the Pigeon.
“I’m not a serpent!” said Alice indignantly. “Let me alone!”
“Serpent, I say again!” repeated the Pigeon, but in a more subdued tone, and added with a kind of sob, “I’ve tried every way, and nothing seems to suit them!”
“I haven’t the least idea what you’re talking about,” said Alice.
“I’ve tried the roots of trees, and I’ve tried banks, and I’ve tried hedges,” the Pigeon went on, without attending to her; “but those serpents! There’s no pleasing them!”
Alice was more and more puzzled, but she thought there was no use in saying anything more till the Pigeon had finished.
“As if it wasn’t trouble enough hatching the eggs,” said the Pigeon; “but I must be on the look-out for serpents night and day! Why, I haven’t had a wink of sleep these three weeks!”
“I’m very sorry you’ve been annoyed,” said Alice, who was beginning to see its meaning.
“And just as I’d taken the highest tree in the wood,” continued the Pigeon, raising its voice to a shriek, “and just as I was thinking I should be free of them at last, they must needs come wriggling down from the sky! Ugh, Serpent!”
“But I’m not a serpent, I tell you!” said Alice. “I’m a—I’m a—”
“Well! What are you?” said the Pigeon. “I can see you’re trying to invent something!”
“I—I’m a little girl,” said Alice, rather doubtfully, as she remembered the number of changes she had gone through that day.
“A likely story indeed!” said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest contempt. “I’ve seen a good many little girls in my time, but never one with such a neck as that! No, no! You’re a serpent; and there’s no use denying it. I suppose you’ll be telling me next that you never tasted an egg!”
“I have tasted eggs, certainly,” said Alice, who was a very truthful child; “but little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do, you know.”
“I don’t believe it,” said the Pigeon; “but if they do, why then they’re a kind of serpent, that’s all I can say.”
This was such a new idea to Alice, that she was quite silent for a minute or two, which gave the Pigeon the opportunity of adding, “You’re looking for eggs, I know that well enough; and what does it matter to me whether you’re a little girl or a serpent?”
“It matters a good deal to me,” said Alice hastily; “but I’m not looking for eggs, as it happens; and if I was, I shouldn’t want yours: I don’t like them raw.”
“Well, be off, then!” said the Pigeon in a sulky tone, as it settled down again into its nest.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Come, my head’s free at last!” said Alice in a tone of delight, which changed into alarm in another moment, when she found that her shoulders were nowhere to be found: all she could see, when she looked down, was an immense length of neck, which seemed to rise like a stalk out of a sea of green leaves that lay far below her.

She felt a little frightened, but she was so proud of her new length that she stretched it out as far as she could, trying to see what was behind her. Suddenly, a large Pigeon flew into her face, hissing and beating her with its wings.

"Serpent!" it screeched.

"I'm not a serpent!" Alice exclaimed indignantly. "Leave me alone!"

"You are a serpent," the Pigeon insisted mournfully. "Nothing satisfies 'them'—serpents."

Alice looked at it in confusion. "What do you mean?"

"I mean I am searching for a safe place—roots, banks, hedges—away from serpents like you," the Pigeon said, ignoring her protests.

Alice was puzzled but waited patiently. The Pigeon continued, lamenting how hard it was to hatch eggs while constantly watching for serpents, claiming it hadn't slept properly in weeks.

Feeling sympathy, Alice said, "That sounds very difficult."

The Pigeon shrieked, "I just want to find the tallest tree, only to have serpents—like your head—appear from the sky!"

"I'm not a serpent," Alice said again, struggling to define what she was.

"Then tell me who you are!" challenged the Pigeon. "You’re inventing something."

Alice hesitated. "I am a little girl," she said, recalling her recent transformations.

The Pigeon dismissed her with a scoff. "I've never seen a girl with such a long neck. You are a serpent! Do you eat eggs?"

"Yes," Alice admitted, "but little girls eat eggs too."

The Pigeon didn't believe her. "If girls eat eggs, then they are just another kind of serpent."

This idea silenced Alice, and the Pigeon added, "You’re searching for my eggs, and your identity—girl or serpent—doesn't matter to me."

"It matters greatly to me!" Alice retorted. "I am not seeking eggs, and I wouldn't want your raw eggs anyway!"

The Pigeon, sulking, told her to leave and settled back into its nest.

Alice was puzzled but waited patiently. The Pigeon continued, lamenting how hard it was to hatch eggs while constantly watching for serpents, claiming it hadn’t slept properly in weeks.

Feeling some sympathy, Alice said, “That sounds very difficult.”

The Pigeon shrieked, “I just want to find the tallest tree, only to have serpents—like your head—appear from the sky!”

“I’m not a serpent,” Alice said again, struggling to define what she was.

“Then tell me who you are!” challenged the Pigeon. “You’re inventing something.”

Alice hesitated. “I am a little girl,” she said, recalling her recent transformations.

The Pigeon dismissed her with a scoff. “I’ve never seen a girl with such a long neck. You are a serpent! Do you eat eggs?”

“Yes,” Alice admitted, “but little girls eat eggs too.”

The Pigeon didn’t believe her. “If girls eat eggs, then they are just another kind of serpent.”

This idea silenced Alice, and the Pigeon added, “You’re searching for my eggs, and your identity—girl or serpent—doesn’t matter to me.”

“It matters greatly to me!” Alice retorted. “I am not seeking eggs, and I wouldn’t want your raw eggs anyway!”

The Pigeon, sulking, told her to leave and settled back into its nest.
