events.title: Gardeners Painting Roses
detailed_summary: Alice observed three gardeners painting white roses red on a large rose tree near the garden entrance.
She overheard them arguing, with Five blaming Seven for jogging his elbow and splashing paint.
Seven accused Five of blaming others, and Five retorted that the Queen wanted Seven beheaded for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.
Seven started to protest the injustice but stopped abruptly upon noticing Alice watching.
All three gardeners bowed low to Alice.
Alice timidly asked why they were painting the roses.
Two explained, prompted by the silence of Five and Seven, that they had mistakenly planted a white rose tree instead of a red one.
He elaborated that they feared the Queen would have them all beheaded if she discovered the mistake.
They were hastily trying to paint the roses red before the Queen's arrival.
Suddenly, Five shouted a warning that the Queen was coming, and the three gardeners immediately prostrated themselves on the ground.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.

events.text_segment:
A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red. Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of them say, “Look out now, Five! Don’t go splashing paint over me like that!”
“I couldn’t help it,” said Five, in a sulky tone; “Seven jogged my elbow.”
On which Seven looked up and said, “That’s right, Five! Always lay the blame on others!”
“You’d better not talk!” said Five. “I heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!”
“What for?” said the one who had spoken first.
“That’s none of your business, Two!” said Seven.
“Yes, it is his business!” said Five, “and I’ll tell him—it was for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.”
Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun “Well, of all the unjust things—” when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and all of them bowed low.
“Would you tell me,” said Alice, a little timidly, “why you are painting those roses?”
Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two. Two began in a low voice, “Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a red rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know. So you see, Miss, we’re doing our best, afore she comes, to—” At this moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called out “The Queen! The Queen!” and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces. There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red.

"What are you doing?" Alice asked. The gardeners looked up and bowed low.

"We're painting the roses red," said Two.

"Why are you painting them?" Alice inquired.

"Because we planted a white rose-tree instead of a red one," explained Two. "And if the Queen finds out, she'll have us beheaded."

"Oh!" Alice exclaimed, feeling rather nervous.

"Five was blaming Seven for jogging his elbow and splashing paint," said Seven, crossing his arms.

"Seven accused Five of blaming others," added Five, "and I told him the Queen wanted him beheaded for bringing tulip-roots instead of onions."

Seven started to protest but stopped abruptly when he noticed Alice watching.

All three gardeners bowed low to Alice.

"Why are you painting the roses?" Alice asked timidly.

Two explained, "We were told to make the roses red before the Queen arrives, or else we shall be punished."

Suddenly, Five shouted, "The Queen is coming!" and the gardeners immediately prostrated themselves on the ground.

"Oh!" Alice exclaimed, feeling rather nervous.

"Five was blaming Seven for jogging his elbow and splashing paint," said Seven, crossing his arms.

"Seven accused Five of blaming others," added Five, "and I told him the Queen wanted him beheaded for bringing tulip-roots instead of onions."

Seven started to protest but stopped abruptly when he noticed Alice watching.

All three gardeners bowed low to Alice.

"Why are you painting the roses?" Alice asked timidly.

Two explained, "We were told to make the roses red before the Queen arrives, or else we shall be punished."

Suddenly, Five shouted, "The Queen is coming!" and the gardeners immediately prostrated themselves on the ground.

events.title: The Royal Procession Arrives
detailed_summary: A procession began, led by ten club-carrying soldiers shaped like playing cards.
Following them were ten courtiers adorned with diamonds, walking in pairs.
Next came ten royal children, decorated with hearts, skipping hand-in-hand in couples.
A group of guests, mainly Kings and Queens, followed, among whom Alice spotted the White Rabbit.
The White Rabbit appeared nervous, smiled at everything, and passed by Alice without recognizing her.
The Knave of Hearts followed, carrying the King's crown on a cushion.
Finally, the King and Queen of Hearts appeared at the end of the grand procession.
Alice considered lying face down like the gardeners but decided against it, reasoning that processions were meant to be seen.

events.text_segment:
First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King’s crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.
Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions; “and besides, what would be the use of a procession,” thought she, “if people had all to lie down upon their faces, so that they couldn’t see it?” So she stood still where she was, and waited.

events.title: Alice Confronts the Queen
detailed_summary: The entire procession halted upon reaching Alice.
The Queen sternly asked the Knave of Hearts to identify Alice, but the Knave only bowed and smiled.
The Queen impatiently called the Knave an idiot and turned to Alice, demanding her name.
Alice politely introduced herself as Alice but privately reminded herself that they were merely a pack of cards and she shouldn't be afraid.
The Queen then pointed to the prostrate gardeners and asked Alice who they were, unable to identify them due to their face-down position and card-like appearance.
Alice, surprising herself with her boldness, replied that it was none of her business.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It’s no business of mine.”

events.text_segment:
When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely “Who is this?” She said it to the Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.
“Idiot!” said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to Alice, she went on, “What’s your name, child?”
“My name is Alice, so please your Majesty,” said Alice very politely; but she added, to herself, “Why, they’re only a pack of cards, after all. I needn’t be afraid of them!”
“And who are these?” said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rose-tree; for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.
“How should I know?” said Alice, surprised at her own courage. “It’s no business of mine.”

events.title: Gardeners Saved, Croquet Invitation Issued
detailed_summary: The Queen became enraged at Alice's response and furiously ordered her execution.
Alice loudly and firmly dismissed the order as nonsense, which silenced the Queen.
The King gently intervened, reminding the Queen that Alice was only a child.
The Queen angrily turned away from the King and ordered the Knave to turn the gardeners over.
The Knave carefully flipped the gardeners using his foot.
The Queen commanded the gardeners to get up, and they immediately did, bowing profusely to everyone.
The Queen yelled at them to stop bowing as it made her dizzy.
Turning to the rose tree, she demanded to know what the gardeners had been doing.
Two humbly began to explain, kneeling, that they were trying to fix their mistake.
The Queen, having examined the roses, cut him off, declared "Off with their heads!", and the procession started moving again.
Three soldiers stayed behind to execute the gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
Alice declared they wouldn't be beheaded and hid them in a large, nearby flower-pot.
The soldiers searched briefly, failed to find the gardeners, and marched off after the procession.
The Queen shouted from a distance, asking if the gardeners' heads were off.
The soldiers shouted back that their heads were gone.
Satisfied, the Queen shouted back, asking if Alice could play croquet.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Yes!” shouted Alice.

events.text_segment:
The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with her head! Off—”
“Nonsense!” said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was silent.
The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said “Consider, my dear: she is only a child!”
The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave “Turn them over!”
The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.
“Get up!” said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everybody else.
“Leave off that!” screamed the Queen. “You make me giddy.” And then, turning to the rose-tree, she went on, “What have you been doing here?”
“May it please your Majesty,” said Two, in a very humble tone, going down on one knee as he spoke, “we were trying—”
“I see!” said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses. “Off with their heads!” and the procession moved on, three of the soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
“You shan’t be beheaded!” said Alice, and she put them into a large flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the others.
“Are their heads off?” shouted the Queen.
“Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!” the soldiers shouted in reply.
“That’s right!” shouted the Queen. “Can you play croquet?”
The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was evidently meant for her.
“Yes!” shouted Alice.

events.title: Joining the Procession and Learning the Duchess's Fate
detailed_summary: The Queen roared for Alice to join them, and Alice entered the procession, curious about future events.

Alice agreed and asked about the Duchess's location.

events.text_segment:
“Come on, then!” roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession, wondering very much what would happen next.
“It’s—it’s a very fine day!” said a timid voice at her side. She was walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.
“Very,” said Alice: “—where’s the Duchess?”
“Hush! Hush!” said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered “She’s under sentence of execution.”
“What for?” said Alice.
“Did you say ‘What a pity!’?” the Rabbit asked.
“No, I didn’t,” said Alice: “I don’t think it’s at all a pity. I said ‘What for?’”
“She boxed the Queen’s ears—” the Rabbit began.

Suddenly, a small, timid voice beside her broke the silence, saying, “It’s such a fine day!” Alice turned to see the White Rabbit, who looked at her with anxious eyes.

“Indeed,” Alice replied, “but do tell me, where is the Duchess?”

The White Rabbit, glancing nervously around, hushed her hurriedly. “Shh! The Duchess is under sentence of execution,” he whispered, leaning close.

“Whatever has she done?” Alice asked, her curiosity piqued.

The Rabbit, mishearing her, exclaimed, “Did you say, ‘What a pity!’?”

“No,” Alice said patiently, “I didn’t think it was a pity. I merely asked about the reason for her sentence.”

The Rabbit then began to explain that the Duchess had been boxing the Queen’s ears, which was the cause of her predicament.

events.title: The Absurdities of the Royal Croquet Game
detailed_summary: Alice couldn't help laughing at the idea of the Duchess boxing the Queen's ears.
The Rabbit frantically hushed her again, afraid the Queen would overhear, mentioning the Duchess had arrived late.
The Queen's thundering voice interrupted, ordering everyone to their places for croquet.

events.text_segment:
Alice gave a little scream of laughter. “Oh, hush!” the Rabbit whispered in a frightened tone. “The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the Queen said—”
“Get to your places!” shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began. Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.
The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo: she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head, it would twist itself round and look up in her face, with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.

In Wonderland, even the wildest dreams seemed to come true, and Alice was eager to see what other adventures awaited her.

events.title: Conversation with the Cheshire Cat
detailed_summary: All players played simultaneously, ignoring turns, constantly arguing, and fighting over the hedgehogs.
The Queen quickly became enraged, stomping around and frequently shouting orders for beheadings.
Alice grew uneasy, realizing that although she hadn't argued with the Queen yet, it could happen anytime, making her wonder about her own fate given the prevalence of executions.
She started looking for an escape route.
While contemplating escape, Alice noticed a peculiar shape materializing in the air.
After observing it, she recognized it as a grin and identified it as the Cheshire Cat, feeling pleased she would have someone to talk to.
The Cat asked Alice how she was doing as soon as its mouth appeared.
Alice waited for its eyes to appear before nodding, thinking it pointless to speak until its ears materialized.
Once the Cat's entire head was visible, Alice put down her flamingo and began describing the game, glad for a listener.
Only the Cat's head became visible; the rest of its body did not appear.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.

events.text_segment:
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.
Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, “and then,” thought she, “what would become of me? They’re dreadfully fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there’s any one left alive!”
She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself “It’s the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.”
“How are you getting on?” said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded. “It’s no use speaking to it,” she thought, “till its ears have come, or at least one of them.” In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.

- The phrase "appearing out of nowhere" is an inaccurate addition, as the original describes a gradual appearance in the air.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Alice watched the scene with a mixture of amusement and concern. The Queen's temper was as fiery as her crown was glittering, and her shouts echoed through the garden like thunder. The cards fluttered around her, trembling with fear, as she ordered their heads to be cut off for the slightest mistake. Alice wondered how such a small creature could be so easily angered, yet she knew that in Wonderland, things were never quite as they seemed. Suddenly, the Queen's voice boomed again, demanding the execution of the White Rabbit, who had been nervously wringing his paws. Alice felt a pang of sympathy for him, but she also realized that in this strange land, justice was often swift and unpredictable. As the Queen continued her tirade, the Cheshire Cat appeared, grinning widely from a nearby tree. "Why, my dear," he said, "it seems the Queen is quite fond of her own temper." Alice giggled at the remark, but she knew she had to find a way to calm the Queen before her head was next on the chopping block. She took a deep breath and stepped forward, determined to restore some order to this chaotic scene, hoping her words would be enough to soothe the Queen's fury.

events.title: Royal Displeasure and Sentence for the Cheshire Cat
detailed_summary: Alice complained to the Cheshire Cat about the unfairness and chaos of the croquet game.
She highlighted the constant quarreling, lack of apparent rules, and confusion caused by the living game pieces like wandering arches and fleeing hedgehogs.
The Cat quietly asked Alice for her opinion of the Queen.
Alice started to express her dislike but noticed the Queen listening nearby.
She quickly modified her sentence to say the Queen was so likely to win that finishing the game seemed pointless.
The Queen smiled at this remark and moved on.
The King approached Alice, asking who she was talking to and observing the Cat's head with curiosity.
Alice introduced the Cat as her friend.
The King expressed his dislike for the Cat's appearance but permitted it to kiss his hand.
The Cat declined the offer.
The King admonished the Cat for impertinence and its stare, hiding behind Alice.
Alice remarked that she'd read somewhere that a cat may look at a king.
The King firmly declared the Cat must be removed and called the Queen over.
He requested that the Queen have the Cat removed.
The Queen, without hesitation or looking, issued her standard solution: "Off with his head!"
The King eagerly volunteered to fetch the executioner himself and rushed away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I’ll fetch the executioner myself,” said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.

events.text_segment:
“I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”
“How do you like the Queen?” said the Cat in a low voice.
“Not at all,” said Alice: “she’s so extremely—” Just then she noticed that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on, “—likely to win, that it’s hardly worth while finishing the game.”
The Queen smiled and passed on.
“Who are you talking to?” said the King, going up to Alice, and looking at the Cat’s head with great curiosity.
“It’s a friend of mine—a Cheshire Cat,” said Alice: “allow me to introduce it.”
“I don’t like the look of it at all,” said the King: “however, it may kiss my hand if it likes.”
“I’d rather not,” the Cat remarked.
“Don’t be impertinent,” said the King, “and don’t look at me like that!” He got behind Alice as he spoke.
“A cat may look at a king,” said Alice. “I’ve read that in some book, but I don’t remember where.”
“Well, it must be removed,” said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, “My dear! I wish you would have this cat removed!”
The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small. “Off with his head!” she said, without even looking round.
“I’ll fetch the executioner myself,” said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “And what a curious game croquet is!” Alice continued, her voice tinged with wonder and a little frustration. “Why, the balls are live creatures, and the mallets are the same! I’ve never seen anything quite like it. The Queen, she’s so particular about her rules, but it’s all so muddled—one moment she’s shouting for order, and the next she’s laughing at the absurdity of it all. The cards are fluttering about, painting the roses red, and the Queen keeps insisting that everyone must be polite, yet she herself is quite the opposite. I do wish I could understand the rules better, or at least find a way to make sense of this strange game. It’s all so confusing, yet somehow fascinating. I suppose that’s what makes Wonderland so unique—nothing is quite as it seems, and everything is a little bit mad. Still, I can’t help feeling a bit overwhelmed by the chaos, and I wonder if I’ll ever find my way back home. But for now, I suppose I must keep going, through the arch and into whatever adventure awaits next. Perhaps I’ll find some answers, or at least some more curious creatures to talk to.”

events.title: Croquet Chaos and the Executioner's Conundrum
detailed_summary: Hearing the Queen shouting angrily in the distance, Alice decided to check on the croquet game.
She had already heard the Queen sentence three players to execution for missing turns and felt uneasy about the general confusion, which made it hard to know whose turn it was.
Alice went searching for her hedgehog ball.
She found her hedgehog fighting another one, which seemed like a good croquet opportunity.
However, her flamingo mallet had wandered to the other side of the garden and was attempting to fly into a tree.
By the time Alice retrieved the flamingo, the hedgehog fight was over, and both hedgehogs were gone.
Alice noted resignedly that the arches on her side of the ground were also gone.
She tucked the flamingo under her arm to prevent another escape and went back to talk to the Cheshire Cat.
Upon returning, Alice found a large crowd gathered around the Cat's location.
An argument was in progress between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, all talking simultaneously, while everyone else looked uncomfortable and remained silent.
Alice was immediately asked by all three to settle the dispute.
They repeated their arguments, though Alice struggled to understand them as they all spoke at once.
The executioner argued he couldn't behead something without a body, stating he'd never done it before and wouldn't start now.
The King argued that anything with a head could be beheaded and dismissed the executioner's point as nonsense.
The Queen argued that if the issue wasn't resolved instantly, she would have everyone executed, which caused widespread anxiety.
Alice suggested asking the Duchess about the Cat, as it belonged to her.
The Queen ordered the executioner to fetch the Duchess from prison.
The executioner dashed off.
As soon as the executioner left, the Cheshire Cat's head began to fade.
By the time the executioner returned with the Duchess, the Cat's head had vanished completely.
The King and executioner searched frantically for the disappeared head, while the rest of the attendees returned to the croquet game.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Cat’s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.

events.text_segment:
Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.
The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree.
By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: “but it doesn’t matter much,” thought Alice, “as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground.” So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.
When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.
The executioner’s argument was, that you couldn’t cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn’t going to begin at his time of life.
The King’s argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren’t to talk nonsense.
The Queen’s argument was, that if something wasn’t done about it in less than no time she’d have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)
Alice could think of nothing else to say but “It belongs to the Duchess: you’d better ask her about it.”
“She’s in prison,” the Queen said to the executioner: “fetch her here.” And the executioner went off like an arrow.
The Cat’s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
She hurried along the corridor, her heart pounding with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension. The Queen's voice echoed louder now, a shrill cry that seemed to shake the very walls of the castle. Alice wondered what could have caused such a commotion. As she turned a corner, she saw the Queen standing at the edge of a vast, checkerboard garden, her face flushed with anger.

"Off with her head!" the Queen shouted, pointing a trembling finger at a small, trembling creature that Alice recognized as the White Rabbit. The rabbit was frantically trying to explain himself, but the Queen was too furious to listen.

Alice stepped forward cautiously, her eyes wide with concern. "Please, Your Majesty," she said softly, "what is the matter?"

The Queen spun around, her eyes blazing. "That foolish rabbit has lost his way and dared to question my authority!" she exclaimed. "He must be punished!"

Alice looked at the scene before her, feeling a strange mixture of fear and resolve. She knew she had to do something to calm the Queen. "Your Majesty," she said gently, "perhaps we could listen to what the rabbit has to say. Sometimes, a little patience can prevent much trouble."

The Queen hesitated, her face twitching with anger, but then she took a deep breath and nodded. "Very well," she snapped. "Speak, rabbit."

The White Rabbit, trembling, explained that he had simply been trying to find his way back to his burrow and had not intended any disrespect. The Queen listened, her expression softening slightly. Alice felt a flicker of hope.

"See?" Alice said softly. "Sometimes, understanding can resolve even the fiercest of tempers."

The Queen looked at Alice, her eyes narrowing. "You speak wisely, girl," she said. "But remember, in my kingdom, I am the law."

Alice nodded, feeling a newfound confidence. "I understand, Your Majesty."

Just then, the Queen's courtiers arrived, whispering hurriedly among themselves. The Queen turned to them and declared, "Let us proceed with the game. But be vigilant!"

As the Queen resumed her place, Alice felt a sense of relief. She had managed to intervene and prevent a catastrophe. She looked around at the strange, whimsical world she was in, realizing that even in chaos, kindness and understanding could make a difference.

With that thought, Alice decided it was time to continue her adventure, eager to see what other wonders and challenges awaited her in this curious land.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER IX. The Mock Turtle’s Story

events.title: Alice and the Moralizing Duchess
detailed_summary: The Duchess expresses great happiness at seeing Alice again, linking arms with her companionably.
Alice reciprocates the pleasure, finding the Duchess in a surprisingly good mood and privately theorizing that pepper was the cause of her earlier ill temper in the kitchen.

Alice internally reflects on becoming a Duchess herself and banning pepper, leading her to develop a theory that various foods influence personality: pepper causes hot tempers, vinegar causes sourness, camomile causes bitterness, and sweets cause sweet tempers.
Lost in thought, Alice is startled when the Duchess points out her abstraction, promising to find the moral of it later.
Alice tentatively suggests that perhaps not everything possesses a moral.
The Duchess dismisses this, insisting on the universality of morals if one looks for them, and presses closer to Alice.
Alice feels uncomfortable with the Duchess's proximity due to her perceived ugliness and the awkwardness of the Duchess resting her sharp chin on Alice's shoulder, but endures it to avoid rudeness.
To maintain conversation, Alice remarks that the croquet game seems to be proceeding better.
The Duchess agrees, offering the moral that love makes the world go round.
Alice quietly shares a different saying: that the world turns because everyone minds their own business.
The Duchess considers this much the same, digs her chin into Alice's shoulder again, and provides another moral concerning the relationship between sense and sounds.
Alice silently observes the Duchess's persistent habit of finding morals everywhere.
The Duchess pauses, then explains she refrains from putting her arm around Alice's waist because she is unsure about the temperament of Alice's flamingo croquet mallet, asking if she should test it.
Alice cautiously discourages the experiment, warning that the flamingo might bite.
The Duchess agrees, noting that both flamingoes and mustard bite, and derives the moral 'Birds of a feather flock together'.
Alice logically points out that mustard is not a bird.
The Duchess compliments Alice's clarity and readily agrees.
Alice tentatively identifies mustard as a mineral.
The Duchess concurs enthusiastically, inventing a nearby mustard mine and offering a moral about ownership: 'The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.'
Alice, not having paid attention to the last moral, corrects herself, stating mustard is a vegetable.
The Duchess agrees once more, giving the moral 'Be what you would seem to be', followed immediately by an extraordinarily long and confusing elaboration of the same principle.
Alice politely responds that she would grasp the lengthy moral better if it were written down, as she cannot follow it when spoken.
The Duchess replies with satisfaction that she could say much more if she desired.
Alice requests that the Duchess not exert herself further.
The Duchess waves off the idea of trouble, declaring she gifts Alice everything she has said so far.
Alice privately thinks this is a worthless gift and is glad birthday presents aren't similar, but keeps the thought to herself.
The Duchess jabs Alice with her chin again, asking if she is thinking once more.
Alice sharply affirms her right to think, feeling increasingly bothered.
The Duchess retorts that Alice's right to think is comparable to pigs' right to fly and begins to state the moral...

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Just about as much right,” said the Duchess, “as pigs have to fly; and the m—”

events.text_segment:
“You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.
Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.
“When I’m a Duchess,” she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), “I won’t have any pepper in my kitchen at all. Soup does very well without—Maybe it’s always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,” she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, “and vinegar that makes them sour—and camomile that makes them bitter—and—and barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn’t be so stingy about it, you know—”
She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear. “You’re thinking about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can’t tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit.”
“Perhaps it hasn’t one,” Alice ventured to remark.
“Tut, tut, child!” said the Duchess. “Everything’s got a moral, if only you can find it.” And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice’s side as she spoke.
Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the Duchess was very ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the right height to rest her chin upon Alice’s shoulder, and it was an uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she bore it as well as she could.
“The game’s going on rather better now,” she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.
“’Tis so,” said the Duchess: “and the moral of that is—‘Oh, ’tis love, ’tis love, that makes the world go round!’”
“Somebody said,” Alice whispered, “that it’s done by everybody minding their own business!”
“Ah, well! It means much the same thing,” said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice’s shoulder as she added, “and the moral of that is—‘Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of themselves.’”
“How fond she is of finding morals in things!” Alice thought to herself.
“I dare say you’re wondering why I don’t put my arm round your waist,” the Duchess said after a pause: “the reason is, that I’m doubtful about the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?”
“He might bite,” Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.
“Very true,” said the Duchess: “flamingoes and mustard both bite. And the moral of that is—‘Birds of a feather flock together.’”
“Only mustard isn’t a bird,” Alice remarked.
“Right, as usual,” said the Duchess: “what a clear way you have of putting things!”
“It’s a mineral, I think,” said Alice.
“Of course it is,” said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to everything that Alice said; “there’s a large mustard-mine near here. And the moral of that is—‘The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.’”
“Oh, I know!” exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark, “it’s a vegetable. It doesn’t look like one, but it is.”
“I quite agree with you,” said the Duchess; “and the moral of that is—‘Be what you would seem to be’—or if you’d like it put more simply—‘Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.’”
“I think I should understand that better,” Alice said very politely, “if I had it written down: but I can’t quite follow it as you say it.”
“That’s nothing to what I could say if I chose,” the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.
“Pray don’t trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,” said Alice.
“Oh, don’t talk about trouble!” said the Duchess. “I make you a present of everything I’ve said as yet.”
“A cheap sort of present!” thought Alice. “I’m glad they don’t give birthday presents like that!” But she did not venture to say it out loud.
“Thinking again?” the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.
“I’ve a right to think,” said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.
“Just about as much right,” said the Duchess, “as pigs have to fly; and the m—”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!" said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.

The Duchess’s face was quite a different color from what it had been when Alice last saw her, and she was in a surprisingly good humor.

"I think pepper was the cause of her ill temper in the kitchen," Alice thought to herself, privately. "If I were a Duchess, I’d ban pepper altogether."

She began to theorize about foods and their effects on temperaments: pepper makes hot tempers, vinegar sourness, chamomile bitterness, and sweets—well, sweets make a sweet temper.

Lost in her thoughts, Alice was startled when the Duchess suddenly pointed out her abstraction.

"I’ll find the moral of it later," the Duchess promised.

"Perhaps not everything has a moral," Alice ventured.

"Nonsense!" said the Duchess. "If you look for morals, you’ll find them everywhere."

She pressed closer to Alice, whose discomfort grew as the Duchess’s sharp chin rested on her shoulder.

"The game of croquet is going better," Alice remarked, trying to change the subject.

"Yes," said the Duchess, "and the moral is that love makes the world go round."

"Or," Alice added softly, "that the world turns because everyone minds their own business."

The Duchess considered this, then pressed her chin into Alice’s shoulder again, offering another moral about sense and sounds.

Alice watched her, noting her habit of finding morals everywhere.

After a pause, the Duchess explained she didn’t put her arm around Alice’s waist because she was unsure about her flamingo croquet mallet’s temperament—should she test it?

"Better not," Alice warned, "it might bite."

"Both flamingoes and mustard bite," the Duchess said, "so the moral is that birds of a feather flock together."

"Mustard isn’t a bird," Alice pointed out.

"No, but it’s a mineral," the Duchess agreed, "and I could tell you about the mustard mine I own—more of mine, less of yours."

"Mustard is a vegetable," Alice corrected, not having paid attention.

"Exactly," said the Duchess, "and the moral is to be what you would seem to be," then elaborated at length on the same principle.

Alice said she’d understand it better if it were written down, as she couldn’t follow it when spoken.

"I could say much more if I liked," the Duchess replied.

"Please don’t," Alice begged.

"Nonsense! I give you everything I’ve said so far," the Duchess declared.

Alice thought it was a worthless gift but kept her thoughts to herself.

The Duchess jabbed her chin again, asking if she was thinking.

"Yes," Alice snapped, feeling increasingly annoyed.

"Your right to think," the Duchess retorted, "is just like pigs’ right to fly," and she began to state the moral...

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Alice felt a warm glow of happiness at the Duchess's words. It had been a long, curious journey through Wonderland, filled with strange creatures and peculiar sights, but now, in this moment, she was comforted by the familiarity of her friends. As they strolled along the winding garden path, the Duchess continued, "You know, Alice, Wonderland is a place of endless surprises, but it's always better when shared with someone you trust."

Alice nodded, her eyes wide with wonder. "I’ve met so many odd characters here—like the Cheshire Cat, who can disappear and reappear at will, and the Mad Hatter, who’s always having a tea party."

The Duchess chuckled softly. "Yes, those are quite the characters. But remember, Alice, not everything in Wonderland is as strange as it seems. Sometimes, it’s just a matter of looking at things from a different perspective."

They reached a small clearing where a group of playing cards were busy painting roses red. The Queen of Hearts was nearby, shouting orders and waving her scepter. Alice watched her with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension.

"The Queen is quite fond of her roses," the Duchess remarked. "She’s a bit quick-tempered, but she means well. Just don’t upset her, or she might order your head!"

Alice giggled nervously. "I’ll be careful. I don’t want to lose my head over a garden of roses."

As they continued their walk, Alice noticed a peculiar creature approaching—a small, grinning cat with a wide, mischievous smile. It was the Cheshire Cat.

"Good day!" Alice called out.

"Good day!" the Cat replied, its grin widening. "Where are you off to, Alice?"

"I’m just exploring," Alice said. "It’s all so strange and wonderful."

"That’s the spirit," the Cat said. "In Wonderland, the only way to understand it is to embrace the oddities."

The Duchess looked at Alice thoughtfully. "You see, Alice, Wonderland is a place where the rules are different, but that doesn’t mean they’re any less real. Sometimes, you have to accept the strange to find your way."

Alice nodded, pondering her adventures. She remembered the time she grew to an enormous size after eating a cake, and the time she shrank down tiny enough to walk through a keyhole. Each experience had taught her something new about herself and the world around her.

Suddenly, a loud voice interrupted their thoughts. It was the Queen of Hearts, shouting, "Off with her head!" at the playing cards, who hurriedly dropped their brushes and scattered in all directions.

The Queen’s face was red with anger, but her eyes twinkled with mischief. The Duchess whispered to Alice, "Don’t mind her. She’s all bluster. Just keep your wits about you."

Alice felt a little nervous but remembered the advice of her friends. She took a deep breath and smiled. "I think I’ll be just fine," she said softly.

As they moved away from the Queen’s garden, the Duchess turned to Alice. "You see, my dear, Wonderland is a place of contradictions. It’s chaotic yet charming, confusing yet enlightening. The key is to stay true to yourself and enjoy the journey."

Alice looked around at the vibrant scenery—the talking flowers, the curious animals, and the whimsical trees. She realized that each moment was a new adventure, and she was eager to see what lay ahead.

Just then, a white rabbit with a pocket watch hurried past them, muttering, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" Alice watched him disappear into a burrow, and her curiosity was piqued.

"I wonder where he’s going," Alice said.

"Probably to a very important appointment," the Duchess replied with a wink.

Alice chuckled and followed the rabbit’s trail, feeling a renewed sense of excitement. She knew that Wonderland was a place where anything could happen, and she was ready to embrace it all.

As they continued their walk, the sky above them shifted from bright blue to a soft pink, signaling the approach of evening. The air was filled with the scent of blooming flowers and the sound of distant laughter.

Alice looked up at the sky and thought about her home, wondering if she would ever find her way back. But for now, she was content to enjoy the magic of Wonderland, surrounded by friends and the endless possibilities that awaited.

The Duchess squeezed Alice’s arm gently. "Remember, Alice, the most important thing is to stay curious and brave. Wonderland is a mirror of your own imagination—what you believe, you can achieve."

Alice smiled, feeling a newfound confidence. She was no longer just a girl lost in a strange land; she was a brave explorer, ready to face whatever came next.

And so, hand in hand with her dear friend, the Duchess, Alice continued her journey through Wonderland, eager to discover the next wonder, the next surprise, and the next lesson that awaited her in this extraordinary world.

events.title: The Queen's Intervention and Game's End
detailed_summary: The Duchess abruptly falls silent mid-word ('moral'), and her arm linked with Alice's begins to shake.
Alice looks up to see the Queen standing before them, arms folded, looking furious.
In a weak voice, the Duchess attempts a polite greeting to the Queen.
The Queen ignores the greeting and shouts an ultimatum at the Duchess: remove herself or her head immediately.
The Duchess makes her choice and disappears instantly.
The Queen instructs Alice, who is too frightened to speak, to resume the croquet game.
Alice slowly follows the Queen back to the playing area.
The other players, who had been resting in the shade during the Queen's absence, scramble back to the game upon her return, warned by the Queen that any delay would result in their deaths.
Throughout the remainder of the game, the Queen continuously argues with players and shouts 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her head!'
The soldiers, previously serving as croquet arches, have to leave their positions to escort the condemned players into custody.
Consequently, after about half an hour, no arches are left on the ground, and all players, apart from the King, the Queen, and Alice, have been arrested and sentenced to execution.
Finally, the Queen stops, completely out of breath.

events.text_segment:
But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.
“A fine day, your Majesty!” the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.
“Now, I give you fair warning,” shouted the Queen, stamping on the ground as she spoke; “either you or your head must be off, and that in about half no time! Take your choice!”
The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.
“Let’s go on with the game,” the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the croquet-ground.
The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen’s absence, and were resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment’s delay would cost them their lives.
All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and under sentence of execution.
Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, “Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?”

events.title: Journey to the Mock Turtle
detailed_summary: Alice replies that she has not seen the Mock Turtle and doesn't even know what one is.
The Queen explains it's the creature from which Mock Turtle Soup is derived.
Alice reiterates she has never encountered or heard of such a creature.
The Queen invites Alice to come along, stating the Mock Turtle will recount his history to her.
As they depart, Alice hears the King quietly announce to the remaining group that they are all pardoned.
Alice silently expresses relief at this news, having been distressed by the number of executions ordered.
They quickly arrive at a spot where a Gryphon is fast asleep in the sun.
The Queen rouses the Gryphon, instructing it to take Alice to meet the Mock Turtle and hear his story.
The Queen explains she must return to oversee some executions and departs, leaving Alice with the Gryphon.
Alice feels uneasy about the Gryphon but judges staying with it to be as safe as pursuing the 'savage' Queen, so she waits.
The Gryphon sits up, rubs its eyes, watches the Queen until she is gone, and then chuckles.
It remarks, partly to itself and partly to Alice, 'What fun!'
When Alice inquires what is fun, the Gryphon clarifies it refers to the Queen.
The Gryphon assures Alice that the Queen's talk of executions is merely 'her fancy' and that nobody is ever actually executed, urging Alice to 'Come on!'
Alice follows slowly, reflecting internally that she has never been ordered around so much in her life.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”

events.text_segment:
“No,” said Alice. “I don’t even know what a Mock Turtle is.”
“It’s the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,” said the Queen.
“I never saw one, or heard of one,” said Alice.
“Come on, then,” said the Queen, “and he shall tell you his history,”
As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice, to the company generally, “You are all pardoned.” “Come, that’s a good thing!” she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don’t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) “Up, lazy thing!” said the Queen, “and take this young lady to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered;” and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.
The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled. “What fun!” said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.
“What is the fun?” said Alice.
“Why, she,” said the Gryphon. “It’s all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!”
“Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: "No," said Alice.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: "No," said Alice.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
“No,” said Alice. “I’ve never seen a Mock Turtle, and I don’t know what one is.”

“Come on, then,” said the Queen, jumping up in a hurry. “You’d better come and see the Mock Turtle. I’ll take you to his house—his den—wherever it is.”

The Queen was so eager to get Alice to see the Mock Turtle that she hurried her along, and Alice, feeling a little nervous but curious, followed. As they moved away, Alice heard the King quietly say to the others, “You’re all pardoned.”

Alice felt a wave of relief wash over her, glad to hear it, as she had been quite distressed by the number of executions ordered.

Soon, they arrived at a shady spot where a Gryphon was sleeping in the sun. The Queen called out, “Gryphon! Wake up! I want you to take Alice to see the Mock Turtle and hear his story.”

The Queen then explained she had to leave to oversee some executions and hurried off, leaving Alice with the Gryphon.

Alice felt a bit uneasy about the Gryphon but thought it was safer to stay with it than to follow the Queen, so she waited.

The Gryphon sat up, rubbed its eyes, and watched the Queen until she disappeared from sight, then chuckled.

“What fun!” the Gryphon exclaimed, partly to itself and partly to Alice.

“What is fun?” Alice asked.

“The Queen’s talk of executions,” the Gryphon replied, “is just her fancy. Nobody is ever actually executed. Come on!”

Alice followed slowly, thinking to herself that she had never been ordered around so much in her life.

The cards fluttered and fell, one by one, at her feet, their faces blank and their suits fluttering in the breeze. Alice looked down at the heap of cards, feeling a strange mixture of fear and amusement. She wondered how she had come to be in this peculiar place, where the sky was a vivid blue and the grass was a lush green, and everything seemed to be made of paper or cardboard. Suddenly, a loud voice boomed from behind her, startling her so much that she nearly dropped her teacup. It was the Queen of Hearts, riding a giant flamingo, with a stern look on her face. “Off with her head!” the Queen commanded, but Alice, feeling braver now, stood her ground. “I’m not afraid of you,” she declared, “and I won’t be bullied by a pack of cards.” The Queen looked surprised, but then she burst into a loud laugh, and the cards scattered in all directions. Alice felt a strange sense of relief and curiosity. She wondered what adventures awaited her next in this strange, whimsical world, where nothing was quite as it seemed, and every moment was a new surprise.

events.title: The Mock Turtle's Tale of Education
detailed_summary: They soon see the Mock Turtle in the distance, appearing sad and lonely on a rock ledge, sighing audibly as they approach.
Alice feels deep sympathy and asks the Gryphon the cause of his sorrow.
The Gryphon dismisses the Mock Turtle's sadness as 'all his fancy,' insisting he has no real sorrow, and again says, 'Come on!'
They go up to the Mock Turtle, who observes them with large, tear-filled eyes but remains silent.
The Gryphon introduces Alice, explaining she wants to hear the Mock Turtle's history.
The Mock Turtle agrees in a somber tone, instructing both Alice and the Gryphon to sit down and not speak until he has finished.
They sit, and silence ensues for several minutes; Alice privately wonders how he can finish if he doesn't start, but waits patiently.
The Mock Turtle finally begins with a deep sigh, stating, 'Once... I was a real Turtle.'
This is followed by another long silence, punctuated only by the Gryphon's occasional 'Hjckrrh!' sound and the Mock Turtle's continuous, heavy sobbing.
Alice is tempted to leave after thanking him for the 'story' but senses there must be more to come, so she stays quiet.
The Mock Turtle resumes, calmer but still sobbing intermittently, describing attending school in the sea as a child.
He mentions the master was an old Turtle they called Tortoise.
Alice interrupts to ask why they called him Tortoise if he wasn't one.
The Mock Turtle irritably explains it was a pun ('because he taught us') and calls Alice 'very dull'.
The Gryphon adds that Alice should be ashamed for asking such a simple question, and they both fall silent, looking at Alice, who feels mortified.
Eventually, the Gryphon prompts the Mock Turtle to continue.
The Mock Turtle repeats that they went to school in the sea.
Alice interjects that she never said she didn't believe him.
The Mock Turtle insists she did.
The Gryphon silences Alice before she can respond further.
The Mock Turtle continues, claiming they received the finest education, attending school daily.
Alice mentions she also attended a day-school, suggesting he needn't be so proud.
The Mock Turtle anxiously asks if her school included 'extras'.
Alice confirms learning French and music.
The Mock Turtle then asks about 'washing'.
Alice replies indignantly that they certainly did not learn washing.
Relieved, the Mock Turtle declares Alice's school inferior because his school's bill listed 'French, music, and washing—extra'.
Alice points out that living at the bottom of the sea would make washing unnecessary.
The Mock Turtle sighs that he couldn't afford the extras and only took the standard course.
Alice inquires about the standard course.
The Mock Turtle lists the subjects: 'Reeling and Writhing' first, then Arithmetic branches named 'Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision'.
Alice ventures to ask about 'Uglification'.
The Gryphon reacts with surprise, asking if she truly hasn't heard of it and relating it to the concept of 'beautify,' concluding that if she doesn't know 'uglify,' she must be a simpleton.
Feeling discouraged, Alice turns back to the Mock Turtle and asks about other subjects.

The Mock Turtle enumerates more subjects using his flappers: 'Mystery' (ancient and modern) with 'Seaography,' then 'Drawling,' taught weekly by an old conger-eel master, which included 'Stretching' and 'Fainting in Coils'.
Alice asks what that class was like.
The Mock Turtle states he's too stiff to demonstrate and the Gryphon never learned it.
The Gryphon confirms, explaining he lacked time as he attended the Classics master, an old crab.
The Mock Turtle sighs that he never studied with the crab, who reportedly taught 'Laughing and Grief'.
The Gryphon confirms this, sighing as well, and both creatures cover their faces with their paws.
Alice quickly changes the subject, asking how many hours of lessons they had per day.
The Mock Turtle explains it was ten hours the first day, nine the second, and decreasing daily.
Alice finds this plan peculiar.
The Gryphon explains the term 'lessons' originates from this daily 'lessening' of hours.
This new idea intrigues Alice, and after some thought, she deduces the eleventh day must have been a holiday.
The Mock Turtle confirms it was.
Alice eagerly asks what happened on the twelfth day.
The Gryphon interrupts firmly, declaring that's enough discussion about lessons and instructs the Mock Turtle to talk about games instead.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That’s enough about lessons,” the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: “tell her something about the games now.”

events.text_segment:
They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She pitied him deeply. “What is his sorrow?” she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, “It’s all his fancy, that: he hasn’t got no sorrow, you know. Come on!”
So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.
“This here young lady,” said the Gryphon, “she wants for to know your history, she do.”
“I’ll tell it her,” said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: “sit down, both of you, and don’t speak a word till I’ve finished.”
So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to herself, “I don’t see how he can ever finish, if he doesn’t begin.” But she waited patiently.
“Once,” said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, “I was a real Turtle.”
These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of “Hjckrrh!” from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, “Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,” but she could not help thinking there must be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.
“When we were little,” the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, “we went to school in the sea. The master was an old Turtle—we used to call him Tortoise—”
“Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?” Alice asked.
“We called him Tortoise because he taught us,” said the Mock Turtle angrily: “really you are very dull!”
“You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,” added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, “Drive on, old fellow! Don’t be all day about it!” and he went on in these words:
“Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—”
“I never said I didn’t!” interrupted Alice.
“You did,” said the Mock Turtle.
“Hold your tongue!” added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on.
“We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—”
“I’ve been to a day-school, too,” said Alice; “you needn’t be so proud as all that.”
“With extras?” asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.
“Yes,” said Alice, “we learned French and music.”
“And washing?” said the Mock Turtle.
“Certainly not!” said Alice indignantly.
“Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school,” said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief. “Now at ours they had at the end of the bill, ‘French, music, and washing—extra.’”
“You couldn’t have wanted it much,” said Alice; “living at the bottom of the sea.”
“I couldn’t afford to learn it.” said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. “I only took the regular course.”
“What was that?” inquired Alice.
“Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,” the Mock Turtle replied; “and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.”
“I never heard of ‘Uglification,’” Alice ventured to say. “What is it?”
The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. “What! Never heard of uglifying!” it exclaimed. “You know what to beautify is, I suppose?”
“Yes,” said Alice doubtfully: “it means—to—make—anything—prettier.”
“Well, then,” the Gryphon went on, “if you don’t know what to uglify is, you are a simpleton.”
Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said “What else had you to learn?”
“Well, there was Mystery,” the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers, “—Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: he taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils.”
“What was that like?” said Alice.
“Well, I can’t show it you myself,” the Mock Turtle said: “I’m too stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.”
“Hadn’t time,” said the Gryphon: “I went to the Classics master, though. He was an old crab, he was.”
“I never went to him,” the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: “he taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say.”
“So he did, so he did,” said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.
“And how many hours a day did you do lessons?” said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.
“Ten hours the first day,” said the Mock Turtle: “nine the next, and so on.”
“What a curious plan!” exclaimed Alice.
“That’s the reason they’re called lessons,” the Gryphon remarked: “because they lessen from day to day.”
This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark. “Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?”
“Of course it was,” said the Mock Turtle.
“And how did you manage on the twelfth?” Alice went on eagerly.
“That’s enough about lessons,” the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: “tell her something about the games now.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break.

Alice felt a deep sympathy for the creature, and asked the Gryphon what was the matter.

The Gryphon answered, 'It's all his fancy, he doesn't really want to be so sad.'

They went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large, tearful eyes but said nothing.

The Gryphon then introduced Alice, explaining she wanted to hear the Mock Turtle's story.

The Mock Turtle agreed in a somber tone, telling them to sit down and not speak until he had finished.

They sat, and a long silence ensued; Alice wondered how he could begin if he didn't start, but she waited patiently.

Finally, the Mock Turtle sighed deeply and began, 'Once... I was a real Turtle.'

This was followed by another long silence, broken only by the Gryphon's occasional 'Hjckrrh!' and the Mock Turtle's continuous, heavy sobbing.

Alice was tempted to leave after thanking him for the story, but she sensed there was more to come, so she stayed quiet.

The Mock Turtle resumed, calmer but still sobbing intermittently, describing his school days in the sea as a young Turtle.

He mentioned that his master was an old Turtle called Tortoise.

Alice asked why they called him Tortoise if he wasn't one.

The Mock Turtle explained irritably that it was a pun—'because he taught us'—and called Alice very dull.

The Gryphon added that Alice should be ashamed for asking such a simple question, and they both looked at her, making her feel mortified.

Eventually, the Gryphon prompted the Mock Turtle to continue.

He repeated that they went to school in the sea.

Alice said she never claimed she didn't believe him.

The Mock Turtle insisted she did.

The Gryphon silenced Alice before she could respond further.

The Mock Turtle then said they received the finest education, attending school daily.

Alice mentioned she also attended a day-school, suggesting he needn't be so proud.

The Mock Turtle asked if her school included 'extras'.

Alice confirmed she learned French and music.

The Mock Turtle then asked about 'washing'.

Alice replied indignantly that they certainly did not learn washing.

Relieved, the Mock Turtle declared Alice's school inferior because his school's bill listed 'French, music, and washing—extra'.

Alice pointed out that living at the bottom of the sea would make washing unnecessary.

The Mock Turtle sighed that he couldn't afford the extras and only took the standard course.

Alice inquired about the standard course.

The Mock Turtle listed the subjects: 'Reeling and Writhing' first, then branches of Arithmetic called 'Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision'.

Alice asked about 'Uglification'.

The Gryphon reacted with surprise, asking if she truly hadn't heard of it and relating it to 'beautify', concluding that if she doesn't know 'uglify', she must be a simpleton.

Feeling discouraged, Alice turned back to the Mock Turtle and asked about other subjects.

He enumerated more subjects using his flappers: 'Mystery' (ancient and modern) with 'Seaography,' then 'Drawling,' taught weekly by an old conger-eel master, which included 'Stretching' and 'Fainting in Coils'.

Alice asked what that class was like.

The Mock Turtle said he's too stiff to demonstrate and the Gryphon never learned it.

The Gryphon confirmed, explaining he lacked time as he attended the Classics master, an old crab.

The Mock Turtle sighed that he never studied with the crab, who reportedly taught 'Laughing and Grief'.

The Gryphon confirmed this, sighing as well, and both creatures covered their faces with their paws.

Alice quickly changed the subject, asking how many hours of lessons they had per day.

The Mock Turtle explained it was ten hours the first day, nine the second, and decreasing daily.

Alice found this plan peculiar.

The Gryphon explained the term 'lessons' originates from this daily 'lessening' of hours.

This new idea intrigued Alice, and after some thought, she deduced the eleventh day must have been a holiday.

The Mock Turtle confirmed it was.

Alice eagerly asked what happened on the twelfth day.

The Gryphon interrupted firmly, declaring that's enough discussion about lessons and instructed the Mock Turtle to talk about games instead.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Alice approached cautiously, her curiosity piqued by the melancholy tune of the Mock Turtle's sighs. "What is the matter?" she asked softly, not wanting to startle him. The Mock Turtle looked up, his eyes filled with a deep sadness, and he sighed again before replying, "Oh, dear Alice, I have lost my way in the sea of memories, and I cannot find my way back to the shore of happiness."

Alice sat down beside him, her brow furrowing with concern. "Can I help you?" she offered kindly. The Mock Turtle nodded slowly, a tear slipping down his cheek. "Perhaps you can. You see, I am trying to remember the song of the sea, the song that once made the waves dance and the stars shimmer. But now, all I hear are echoes of sorrow."

"Would you like me to sing for you?" Alice asked gently, eager to lift his spirits. The Mock Turtle looked at her with a glimmer of hope. "Oh, yes, please! That would be most kind." Alice cleared her throat and began to sing a soft, melodious tune, inspired by the gentle lullabies she had heard in her dreams.

As her voice floated through the air, the Mock Turtle's expression softened, and a faint smile appeared on his face. The song seemed to weave a magic spell, calming the turbulent waves of his memories. When she finished, he clapped his flippers together happily. "Thank you, Alice. Your song has brought back a fragment of the sea's joy."

They sat in silence for a moment, watching the ripples in the water below. Alice wondered aloud, "Do you remember how the sea used to sing?" The Mock Turtle nodded wistfully. "Indeed, I do. It was a song of longing and laughter, of adventures and dreams. But now, the song is lost in the depths of my mind."

"Maybe I can help you find it," Alice suggested brightly. "Sometimes, all it takes is a little imagination and a lot of courage." The Mock Turtle looked at her with admiration. "You are a brave girl, Alice. Perhaps together, we can rediscover the melody of the sea."

With renewed hope, they set off along the rocky ledge, Alice humming softly to herself. As they moved, the Mock Turtle began to recall fragments of the song, his voice joining hers in a tentative harmony. The melody grew stronger, filling the air with a sense of wonder and possibility.

Suddenly, they reached a small cove where the water was crystal clear, and the sunlight danced on the surface. The Mock Turtle paused, gazing into the depths. "This is where the song begins," he whispered. "Listen closely." Alice leaned in, her ears attuned to the gentle lapping of the waves.

From the depths, a faint, enchanting tune emerged—a melody that seemed to carry the very essence of the sea. It was a song of hope, of dreams yet to be realized, and of the endless horizon that beckoned. Alice closed her eyes, letting the music wash over her, feeling the rhythm of the waves and the heartbeat of the ocean.

As the song swelled, the Mock Turtle's eyes sparkled with renewed life. "I remember now!" he exclaimed. "The song is about the journey, the adventures we have, and the friends we meet along the way. It is about finding joy even in the darkest depths."

Alice smiled warmly. "Then let us sing it together," she said. And so, they sang, their voices blending with the natural symphony of the sea. The melody carried them across the cove, over the rocks, and into the open waters beyond.

With each note, the Mock Turtle's sadness lifted, replaced by a gentle happiness that shimmered like sunlight on the waves. Alice felt a lightness in her heart, knowing that she had helped a friend find his song again. As they finished, the sea seemed to applaud with a chorus of gentle splashes and whispers.

They continued their journey along the coast, the Mock Turtle now singing softly to himself, a song of hope and renewal. Alice marveled at the magic of the moment, realizing that sometimes, all it takes to heal a broken heart is a kind word, a gentle song, and the courage to listen to the music within.

As the sun dipped lower in the sky, casting a golden glow over the water, Alice and the Mock Turtle sat together on a sandy patch, watching the horizon where the sky met the sea. The Mock Turtle turned to Alice and said, "Thank you, dear Alice. You have reminded me of the beauty that still exists in the world, even in the depths of sorrow."

Alice nodded, feeling a warm glow of happiness. "Remember, no matter how dark the night, the dawn will always come. And with it, new songs to sing and new adventures to embrace."

The Mock Turtle smiled, a genuine smile that reached his eyes. "I shall carry your words with me, Alice. And I shall sing the song of the sea with renewed spirit, sharing its melody with all who listen."

With that, they parted ways, each carrying a piece of the other's kindness and hope. Alice continued her journey through Wonderland, her heart lighter and her mind filled with the melodies of friendship and discovery. And somewhere, in the depths of the sea, the song of the Mock Turtle echoed softly, a reminder that even in sadness, there is always a song waiting to be rediscovered.

events.title: Mock Turtle's Sorrow and Introduction to the Lobster Quadrille
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle expresses deep sadness, unable to speak through sobs.
The Gryphon physically assists the Mock Turtle to help him regain his voice, comparing the choking sound to having a bone in the throat.
With tears, the Mock Turtle resumes speaking to Alice.
He suggests Alice lacks understanding of undersea life, having likely never lived there or been introduced to a lobster.
Alice confirms her lack of undersea experience and, after almost mentioning tasting lobster, denies ever being introduced to one.
The Mock Turtle concludes that Alice cannot comprehend the delight of a Lobster Quadrille.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “—so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!”

events.text_segment:
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice. “Same as if he had a bone in his throat,” said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:—
“You may not have lived much under the sea—” (“I haven’t,” said Alice)—“and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster—” (Alice began to say “I once tasted—” but checked herself hastily, and said “No, never”) “—so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!”
