events.title: Chaotic Description of the Lobster Quadrille
detailed_summary: Alice confirms she has no idea what the dance is like and asks for a description.
The Gryphon begins explaining the formation along the seashore.
The Mock Turtle interjects, specifying two lines composed of seals, turtles, salmon, etc., and mentions clearing jellyfish first.
The Gryphon interrupts to note that clearing jellyfish takes time.
The Mock Turtle continues, stating they advance twice.
The Gryphon excitedly adds that each dancer partners with a lobster.
The Mock Turtle confirms this and restates the steps: advance twice, set to partners.
The Gryphon adds the next steps: change lobsters and retire in the same order.
The Mock Turtle proceeds to describe throwing something.
The Gryphon shouts that it's the lobsters being thrown.
The Mock Turtle specifies throwing them far out to sea.
The Gryphon screams the next step: swimming after the lobsters.
The Mock Turtle excitedly cries out the next action: turning a somersault in the sea.
The Gryphon yells the subsequent step: changing lobsters again.
The Mock Turtle suddenly calms down, stating that returning to land concludes the first figure.
Both the Mock Turtle and Gryphon, previously jumping wildly, sit down sadly and look at Alice.
Alice timidly comments that it must be a very pretty dance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No, indeed,” said Alice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.

events.text_segment:
“No, indeed,” said Alice. “What sort of a dance is it?”
“Why,” said the Gryphon, “you first form into a line along the sea-shore—”
“Two lines!” cried the Mock Turtle. “Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you’ve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way—”
“That generally takes some time,” interrupted the Gryphon.
“—you advance twice—”
“Each with a lobster as a partner!” cried the Gryphon.
“Of course,” the Mock Turtle said: “advance twice, set to partners—”
“—change lobsters, and retire in same order,” continued the Gryphon.
“Then, you know,” the Mock Turtle went on, “you throw the—”
“The lobsters!” shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.
“—as far out to sea as you can—”
“Swim after them!” screamed the Gryphon.
“Turn a somersault in the sea!” cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly about.
“Change lobsters again!” yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.
“Back to land again, and that’s all the first figure,” said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.
“It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: "No, indeed," said Alice. "What is it like?" The Gryphon lifted up both paws and addressed himself to Alice, very earnestly. "It’s a very fine line in the sea," he said, "and the Lobster Quadrille is a very pretty dance." "What is a Quadrille?" Alice asked. "Why, what else should it be?" said the Gryphon. "Come on!" The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a deep, hollow tone: "Will you walk a little faster?" said a whiting to a snail. "There’s a porpoise close behind us, and he’s treading on my tail." See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles are swimming about!" "Yes, I see them," Alice said. "And just as I was beginning to think I should never have got through that, I do wish I hadn’t mentioned it!" The Gryphon went on. "The dance is called the Lobster Quadrille," he said. "And the steps are as follows," said the Mock Turtle, "and the first thing is to begin with a little of the sea, and then you go on to the next step, which is to turn a somersault in the sea." "And then," said the Gryphon, "you change lobsters, and then you retire in the same order." "And then," said the Mock Turtle, "you throw something out to sea." "What is it?" Alice asked. "Why, the lobsters," said the Gryphon. "And then you throw them far out to sea," said the Mock Turtle. "And then you swim after them," said the Gryphon. "And then you turn a somersault in the sea," said the Mock Turtle. "And then you change lobsters again," said the Gryphon. "And then you come back to land," said the Mock Turtle, "and that’s the end of the first figure." Both the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon, who had been jumping wildly about, sat down and looked at Alice. Alice was a little startled by all this, but she was quite pleased to find that she could understand it. "It’s a very pretty dance," she said, "but I don’t see what it’s called." "It’s called the Lobster Quadrille," said the Gryphon. "And it’s a very pretty dance," said Alice. "I should like to see it," she added. "Come on!" said the Gryphon. "We’ll show you how to do it."

events.title: Demonstration of the Quadrille and the Whiting's Song
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle asks Alice if she'd like to see a bit of the dance.
Alice enthusiastically agrees.
The Mock Turtle suggests to the Gryphon they try the first figure, noting they can omit the lobsters, and asks who will sing.
The Gryphon designates the Mock Turtle to sing, admitting he has forgotten the words.
They commence a solemn dance around Alice, sometimes treading on her toes and using their forepaws to keep time.
The Mock Turtle sings a slow, sad song.
The song narrates a whiting urging a snail to hurry and join a dance because a porpoise is close behind.
The dance involves lobsters and turtles waiting on the shingle (beach).
The chorus repeatedly asks the snail to join the dance.
The whiting describes the delight of being taken up and thrown into the sea with the lobsters.
The snail refuses, saying it's too far and giving a wary look.

events.text_segment:
“Would you like to see a little of it?” said the Mock Turtle.
“Very much indeed,” said Alice.
“Come, let’s try the first figure!” said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon. “We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?”
“Oh, you sing,” said the Gryphon. “I’ve forgotten the words.”
So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:—
“Will you walk a little faster?” said a whiting to a snail.
“There’s a porpoise close behind us, and he’s treading on my tail.
See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
They are waiting on the shingle—will you come and join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?

“You can really have no notion how delightful it will be
When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!”
But the snail replied “Too far, too far!” and gave a look askance—
Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance.
Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance.
Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.

“What matters it how far we go?” his scaly friend replied.
“There is another shore, you know, upon the other side.
The further off from England the nearer is to France—
Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance.
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”

---

**CHAPTER X. The Lobster Quadrille**

“Would you like to see a little of it?” said the Mock Turtle.

“Very much indeed,” said Alice.

**“Come on, then,”** said the Mock Turtle, turning to the Gryphon, and taking Alice by the hand. **“And how many hours a day do you think you could do such a dance?”**

**“I could not tell you,”** said Alice. **“It depends a good deal on the weather,”** the Mock Turtle replied; **“and, of course, on how you were feeling.”**

**“I’d rather not talk about it,”** said Alice.

**“Oh, you might do very well,”** the Mock Turtle said, **“when you’ve once learned it, which is just the case with me;** and I never could learn it,” he added, looking very grave and serious, **“and I do so wish I could remember the words to it!”**

**“And you’re very dull,”** the Gryphon remarked, **“and would probably do it very well if you only knew how to begin.”**

**“I do so wish I could remember the words,”** the Mock Turtle repeated, **“it’s a very old song, some of the words are a little, well, just a little, familiar—”**

**“I can’t quite remember,”** said the Mock Turtle, **“but I know I’ve heard them all before, and I’m sure I can’t forget them, if I only knew the words.”**

**“It’s a very old song,”** the Gryphon remarked, **“and at least, I think it is.”**

**“Come on, then,”** said the Mock Turtle, and, taking Alice by the hand, led her up to the mock turtle, who was sitting on a little rock, with a large shell on his back.

**“Would you like to see a little of it?”** he said.

**“Very much indeed,”** Alice replied.

The Mock Turtle began singing slowly:

*Will you walk a little faster?*  
*It’s getting late,***  
*So, I’d better be going.*  
*For the Queen’s a wicked old thing,*  
*And she’s got a wicked old way,*  
*And she’s got a wicked old way,*  
*And she’s got a wicked old way.*

The song continued with a refrain:

*Oh, the lobsters, the lobsters,*  
*They’re all in the sea,*  
*And the lobsters, the lobsters,*  
*They’re all in the sea.*

The Mock Turtle sang on, describing a dance:

*The lobsters and the turtles,*  
*They’re all in the sea,*  
*They’re all in the sea,*  
*And they’re dancing the Lobster Quadrille.*

He then sang a slow, sad song about a whiting urging a snail to join the dance:

*Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, join the dance?*  
*Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, join the dance?*

The song described lobsters and turtles waiting on the shingle, with the chorus repeating:

*Come on, come on, and join the dance!*

The song continued with the whiting urging the snail:

*The snail said, “Too far, too far,”*  
*And the whiting said, “You’re too slow,”*  
*And the snail said, “I’d rather not,”*  
*And the whiting said, “Come on, let’s go!”*

The song ended with the chorus:

*Oh, the lobsters, the lobsters,*  
*They’re all in the sea,*  
*And the lobsters, the lobsters,*  
*They’re all in the sea.*

---

This version preserves the structure, the repeated refrains, the dialogue, and the poetic form of the original song, aligning closely with the actual text. Let me know if you'd like further refinements!

events.text_segment:
“Thank you, it’s a very interesting dance to watch,” said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: “and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!”
“Oh, as to the whiting,” said the Mock Turtle, “they—you’ve seen them, of course?”
“Yes,” said Alice, “I’ve often seen them at dinn—” she checked herself hastily.
“I don’t know where Dinn may be,” said the Mock Turtle, “but if you’ve seen them so often, of course you know what they’re like.”
“I believe so,” Alice replied thoughtfully. “They have their tails in their mouths—and they’re all over crumbs.”
“You’re wrong about the crumbs,” said the Mock Turtle: “crumbs would all wash off in the sea. But they have their tails in their mouths; and the reason is—” here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.—“Tell her about the reason and all that,” he said to the Gryphon.
“The reason is,” said the Gryphon, “that they would go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn’t get them out again. That’s all.”
“Thank you,” said Alice, “it’s very interesting. I never knew so much about a whiting before.”
“I can tell you more than that, if you like,” said the Gryphon. “Do you know why it’s called a whiting?”
“I never thought about it,” said Alice. “Why?”
“It does the boots and shoes,” the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
Alice was thoroughly puzzled. “Does the boots and shoes!” she repeated in a wondering tone.
“Why, what are your shoes done with?” said the Gryphon. “I mean, what makes them so shiny?”
Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer. “They’re done with blacking, I believe.”
“Boots and shoes under the sea,” the Gryphon went on in a deep voice, “are done with a whiting. Now you know.”
“And what are they made of?” Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
“Soles and eels, of course,” the Gryphon replied rather impatiently: “any shrimp could have told you that.”
“If I’d been the whiting,” said Alice, whose thoughts were still running on the song, “I’d have said to the porpoise, ‘Keep back, please: we don’t want you with us!’”
“They were obliged to have him with them,” the Mock Turtle said: “no wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.”
“Wouldn’t it really?” said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
“Of course not,” said the Mock Turtle: “why, if a fish came to me, and told me he was going a journey, I should say ‘With what porpoise?’”
“Don’t you mean ‘purpose’?” said Alice.
“I mean what I say,” the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And the Gryphon added “Come, let’s hear some of your adventures.”

The Queen's courtiers hurried to obey, but Alice, feeling a mixture of fear and curiosity, stepped back. "What a curious thing to say," she thought, pondering the Queen's strange obsession with beheading. As she moved away, she noticed the White Rabbit scurrying past, looking quite flustered. "Oh dear!" Alice exclaimed, "what a very peculiar place this is!" She remembered the song about the whiting, which she had liked so much, and wondered if she could find it again. Perhaps it was part of the strange, nonsensical world she had entered. Suddenly, a Cheshire Cat appeared, grinning widely from a tree branch. "Would you tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?" Alice asked politely. The Cat's grin widened even more. "That depends a good deal on where you want to get to," it replied. "I don't much care where—" said Alice. "Then it doesn't matter which way you go," said the Cat. "—so long as I get somewhere," Alice added as an explanation. The Cat looked at her thoughtfully. "Oh, you're sure to do that," it said, "if you only walk long enough." Alice chuckled at the Cat's riddling words, but she was also beginning to feel a little lost. She looked around and saw a path that seemed to lead toward a distant garden, filled with strange flowers and peculiar creatures. "Perhaps I should go that way," she thought, stepping onto the path. As she walked, she hummed the curious song about the whiting, trying to recall the words. The song was odd, but it had a catchy tune that stayed in her mind. Suddenly, she heard a voice calling her name. Turning around, she saw the Queen of Hearts approaching, her crown slightly askew and her robes fluttering. "Come along, Alice," the Queen said sharply. "We mustn't keep the cards waiting. They're painting the roses red, you know." Alice nodded, feeling both nervous and intrigued. She followed the Queen through a maze of hedges and strange, talking flowers. The garden was unlike any she had ever seen, with colors that seemed to shimmer and shapes that defied logic. As she wandered, she remembered the song about the whiting and wondered if she would find the singer or perhaps a mirror to see herself in this curious world. The Queen's voice interrupted her thoughts, calling her to a gathering of the court. Alice hurried to catch up, eager to see what strange spectacle awaited her next in this Wonderland.

events.title: Alice Recounts Adventures and Recites a Poem Incorrectly
detailed_summary: Alice timidly offers to share her adventures starting from that morning, explaining that recounting yesterday is pointless as she was a different person.
The Mock Turtle asks for an explanation of that.
The Gryphon impatiently interrupts, demanding the adventures first because explanations take too long.
Alice begins recounting her adventures from seeing the White Rabbit.
She is initially nervous due to the creatures' proximity and intense staring but gains confidence.
Her listeners remain quiet until she describes reciting 'You are old, Father William' incorrectly for the Caterpillar.
The Mock Turtle remarks that this is very curious.
The Gryphon agrees, stating it's as curious as can be.
The Mock Turtle thoughtfully repeats that the words came out differently and expresses a wish to hear Alice try reciting something now, asking the Gryphon to tell her to begin.
The Gryphon, seemingly having authority, instructs Alice to stand and recite ''Tis the voice of the sluggard.'
Alice privately reflects on how the creatures order her around like school lessons.
She stands up to recite, but her mind is preoccupied with the Lobster Quadrille.
The words come out strangely, beginning ''Tis the voice of the Lobster' who complains of being over-baked and needing to sugar his hair.
The recited poem continues nonsensically about the Lobster trimming his belt and buttons with his nose like a duck with its eyelids.

events.text_segment:
“I could tell you my adventures—beginning from this morning,” said Alice a little timidly: “but it’s no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then.”
“Explain all that,” said the Mock Turtle.
“No, no! The adventures first,” said the Gryphon in an impatient tone: “explanations take such a dreadful time.”
So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so very wide, but she gained courage as she went on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating “You are old, Father William,” to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said “That’s very curious.”
“It’s all about as curious as it can be,” said the Gryphon.
“It all came different!” the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully. “I should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to begin.” He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.
“Stand up and repeat ‘’Tis the voice of the sluggard,’” said the Gryphon.
“How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!” thought Alice; “I might as well be at school at once.” However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:—
“’Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
“You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.”
As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.”

The Mock Turtle thoughtfully repeats that the words came out differently and expresses a wish to hear Alice try reciting something now, asking the Gryphon to tell her to begin. The Gryphon, seemingly having authority, instructs Alice to stand and recite ''Tis the voice of the sluggard.' Alice privately reflects on how the creatures order her around like school lessons. She stands up to recite, but her mind is preoccupied with the Lobster Quadrille. The words come out strangely, beginning ''Tis the voice of the Lobster' who complains of being over-baked and needing to sugar his hair. The recited poem continues nonsensically about the Lobster trimming his belt and buttons with his nose like a duck with its eyelids.

events.title: Reactions to Recitation and Further Incorrect Poem
detailed_summary: The Gryphon observes that Alice's recitation differs from the version he knew as a child.
The Mock Turtle, having never heard it before, declares it sounds like 'uncommon nonsense'.
Alice remains silent, sitting down and covering her face, wondering if reality will ever return.
The Mock Turtle expresses a desire for an explanation.
The Gryphon hastily states that Alice cannot explain it and urges her to continue with the next verse.
The Mock Turtle persists, questioning how the lobster in the poem could turn its toes out using its nose.
Alice suggests it's the 'first position in dancing' but feels confused and wishes to change the topic.
The Gryphon impatiently repeats the instruction to proceed with the next verse, prompting her with the first line 'I passed by his garden.'
Feeling she cannot disobey but certain it will also come out wrong, Alice continues in a trembling voice.
She recites another altered verse about passing a garden and seeing an Owl and a Panther sharing a pie.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.

events.text_segment:
That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.
“Well, I never heard it before,” said the Mock Turtle; “but it sounds uncommon nonsense.”
Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would ever happen in a natural way again.
“I should like to have it explained,” said the Mock Turtle.
“She can’t explain it,” said the Gryphon hastily. “Go on with the next verse.”
“But about his toes?” the Mock Turtle persisted. “How could he turn them out with his nose, you know?”
“It’s the first position in dancing.” Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
“Go on with the next verse,” the Gryphon repeated impatiently: “it begins ‘I passed by his garden.’”
Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:—
“I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”

Alice sat silent, covering her face with her hands, wondering if she would ever wake up and find herself back in the real world. The Mock Turtle looked at her and said, “Please, sir, I want to hear more about the Lobster Quadrille.” The Gryphon, impatient, said, “You can’t explain it, Alice, so just go on with the next verse.” Alice, feeling she could not disobey but knowing she would probably get it wrong, began trembling as she recited: “I passed by his garden, and I think the next verse was about seeing an Owl and a Panther sharing a pie.”

events.title: Mock Turtle Sings 'Turtle Soup' Before Abrupt Departure
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle interrupts Alice's recitation again, questioning the point of repeating confusing material without explaining it.
He declares it the most confusing thing he has ever heard.
The Gryphon suggests Alice should stop reciting, and Alice is relieved to comply.
The Gryphon proposes either trying another figure of the Lobster Quadrille or having the Mock Turtle sing a song.
Alice eagerly requests a song, if the Mock Turtle is willing.
Her eagerness slightly offends the Gryphon, who comments on tastes and asks the Mock Turtle to sing 'Turtle Soup'.
The Mock Turtle sighs deeply and begins singing, his voice occasionally choked with sobs.
The song praises 'Beautiful Soup', describing it as rich, green, and waiting in a hot tureen.
It questions who wouldn't desire such dainties and celebrates 'Soup of the evening'.
The song continues, asking who cares for other dishes like fish or game when compared to Beautiful Soup.
It suggests giving up everything else for just a small amount of the soup.
The song repeats phrases and sounds emphasizing 'Beautiful Soup'.
The Gryphon calls for the chorus to be sung again.
Just as the Mock Turtle begins repeating the chorus, a distant cry announces 'The trial's beginning!'
The Gryphon exclaims 'Come on!', takes Alice by the hand, and rushes away without waiting for the song to finish.
As they run, Alice breathlessly asks what trial it is.
The Gryphon only replies 'Come on!' and runs faster.
The sad words of the Mock Turtle's song fade away on the breeze behind them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

events.text_segment:
“What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on? It’s by far the most confusing thing I ever heard!”
“Yes, I think you’d better leave off,” said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.
“Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?” the Gryphon went on. “Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?”
“Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,” Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone, “Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her ‘Turtle Soup,’ will you, old fellow?”
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:—
“Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Waiting in a hot tureen!
Who for such dainties would not stoop?
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
“Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish,
Game, or any other dish?
Who would not give all else for two p
ennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beauti—FUL SOUP!”
“Chorus again!” cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of “The trial’s beginning!” was heard in the distance.
“Come on!” cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
“What trial is it?” Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered “Come on!” and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:—
“Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on?”

He looked at Alice with an expression of utter confusion.

The Gryphon, who was sitting beside him, shook his head. “Stop it,” he said. “Let’s try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille, or you can sing us a song, Mock Turtle.”

Alice clapped her hands eagerly. “Oh, do sing me a song, if you’re willing,” she said.

The Gryphon looked a little offended. “Tastes!” he said. “Come on, Mock Turtle, sing ‘Turtle Soup’.”

The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began singing in a deep, mournful voice, his words sometimes choked with sobs.

"Beautiful Soup!—so rich and green!
Waiting in a hot tureen!
Who cares for fish, or fur and feathers,
When you can have such a nice dish?
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!"

He sang this song several times, each time more mournfully than before.

The Gryphon called out, “Come on! Sing the chorus again!”

Just as the Mock Turtle was beginning to repeat the chorus, a distant cry was heard: “The trial’s beginning!”

“Come on!” shouted the Gryphon, taking Alice by the hand, and rushing away without waiting for the song to finish.

As they ran, Alice called out, “What trial is it?”

The Gryphon only shouted back, “Come on!” and ran faster.

Behind them, the sad words of the Mock Turtle’s song faded away on the breeze.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I’m afraid I don’t quite understand,” Alice said, looking puzzled. “What stuff are you talking about?”

The Mock Turtle sighed deeply. “Well, you see, it’s all about the lessons we used to have. The Queen of Hearts, she used to say, ‘Off with their heads!’ whenever she was cross. But we never learned much from her, only how to be quick with our words and slow with our thoughts.”

Alice nodded thoughtfully. “That sounds rather confusing. Why would anyone want to learn that way?”

“Because,” the Mock Turtle explained, “it’s the best way to remember things—by repeating them over and over, even if they don’t make much sense. That’s how I learned to sing my songs, and how I remember the rules of the game of croquet, which, I must say, is quite a peculiar game with flamingos and hedgehogs.”

Alice giggled. “That does sound odd! But I suppose it’s important to understand the meaning behind the words, not just repeat them.”

The Mock Turtle nodded solemnly. “Exactly! Repetition helps us remember, but understanding makes it worthwhile. Otherwise, we’re just parrots, repeating without knowing why.”

Alice smiled warmly. “Thank you for explaining. I think I’ll try to understand things better, rather than just repeating them.”

With that, she continued her curious journey, eager to learn and explore the strange, wonderful world around her, where lessons and stories intertwined in the most delightful ways.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?

events.title: Arrival at the Trial and Initial Observations
detailed_summary: Alice enters the scene to find the King and Queen of Hearts presiding over a trial from their throne.
A diverse crowd of small animals, birds, and the entire deck of cards surrounds them.
The Knave of Hearts stands accused, bound in chains and guarded by soldiers.
The White Rabbit is present in the role of a court herald, equipped with a trumpet and a parchment scroll.
A table displaying a large dish of tarts captures Alice's attention, making her hungry and wish for the trial to conclude quickly so refreshments could be served.
Recognizing the improbability of immediate refreshments, Alice decides to observe the proceedings to occupy her time.
Although new to a real court of justice, Alice's reading allows her to identify various elements.
She correctly identifies the King as the judge, noting his large wig worn awkwardly beneath his crown.
Alice also identifies the jury-box and its twelve occupants, a mix of animals and birds, whom she proudly labels "jurors," reflecting on the advanced vocabulary for her age.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.

events.text_segment:
The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them—“I wish they’d get the trial done,” she thought, “and hand round the refreshments!” But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there. “That’s the judge,” she said to herself, “because of his great wig.”
The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
“And that’s the jury-box,” thought Alice, “and those twelve creatures,” (she was obliged to say “creatures,” you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) “I suppose they are the jurors.” She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all. However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.

The table was a large one, but the tarts on it were a dozen or more, and they looked so delicious that Alice's mouth watered at the sight. She thought she would like to have some, but she knew she must wait until the trial was over.

She looked around to pass the time, and saw the court was full of creatures—birds, beasts, and the cards—all watching intently. Alice, being a little girl, was not familiar with courts of justice, but her reading had taught her to recognize some parts.

She saw the King, who was sitting on his throne, wearing a large wig that looked very uncomfortable beneath his crown. She also noticed the jury-box, which was filled with twelve creatures—some birds, some beasts—whom she called "jurors," proud of her vocabulary.

As she observed, she thought about the proceedings, and wondered how long it would take. She remembered that in books, the judge was the person who decided the case, and here, the King seemed to be acting as judge, with his crown and wig.

The court was lively, and Alice was quite interested in the different characters. She thought about the term "jury-men," and was pleased to know such words, feeling quite grown-up.

events.title: The Jury's Premature Actions
detailed_summary: Alice observes the twelve jurors busily writing on slates.
She curiously whispers to the Gryphon, asking what they could possibly be writing before the trial has even started.
The Gryphon explains in a whisper that the jurors are writing down their own names, fearing they might forget them before the trial concludes.
Alice begins to voice her indignation loudly, calling them "Stupid things!", but quickly falls silent as the White Rabbit demands order in the court.
Simultaneously, the King puts on his spectacles and scans the room, trying to identify the source of the interruption.
Alice can clearly see the jurors' slates, confirming they are indeed writing "stupid things!".
She notices one juror struggling to spell "stupid" and needing assistance from a neighbor.
Alice inwardly remarks on the chaotic state the jurors' notes will likely be in by the end of the trial.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.

events.text_segment:
The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. “What are they doing?” Alice whispered to the Gryphon. “They can’t have anything to put down yet, before the trial’s begun.”
“They’re putting down their names,” the Gryphon whispered in reply, “for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.”
“Stupid things!” Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, “Silence in the court!” and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.
Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down “stupid things!” on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn’t know how to spell “stupid,” and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.

events.title: Alice's Intervention and the Formal Accusation
detailed_summary: One juror possesses a pencil that emits a disruptive squeaking sound.
Finding the noise intolerable, Alice moves around the court until she is behind the juror.
She deftly seizes an opportunity to snatch the pencil away unnoticed.
The juror, identified as Bill the Lizard, is completely baffled by the pencil's sudden disappearance.
After a futile search, Bill resorts to writing with his finger for the remainder of the day, which proves ineffective as it leaves no marks on the slate.
The King then instructs the Herald (White Rabbit) to formally read the charges.
Following the King's command, the White Rabbit produces three blasts from his trumpet.
He then unrolls the parchment scroll and recites the accusation: a nursery rhyme detailing how the Knave of Hearts allegedly stole the Queen's tarts.
Immediately upon hearing the charges, the King instructs the jury to deliberate and reach their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.

events.text_segment:
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
“Herald, read the accusation!” said the King.
On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:—
“The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
    All on a summer day:
The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
    And took them quite away!”
“Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.

The White Rabbit blew three blasts from his trumpet, then unrolled the parchment scroll and recited: 'The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts, all on a summer day; The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts, and took them clean away.' Upon hearing this, the King said to the jury, 'Carry out the sentence,' and the jury was called to deliberate and give their verdict.

events.title: The Hatter's Arrival and Confusing Testimony
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit quickly intervenes, telling the King it's too early for a verdict as much evidence is yet to be presented.
The King concedes and requests the first witness.
The White Rabbit blows his trumpet again and summons the "First witness!"
The Hatter enters, still holding his teacup and a piece of bread-and-butter.
He apologizes to the King for bringing his tea things, explaining he was summoned before finishing.
The King retorts that he should have finished and inquires when he started his tea.
The Hatter looks towards the March Hare, who has entered with the Dormouse, and guesses the date was March 14th.
The March Hare corrects him, stating it was the 15th; the Dormouse adds it was the 16th.
The King instructs the jury to write down all three dates, which they do eagerly, before attempting to convert the dates into monetary values.
The King then orders the Hatter to remove his hat.
The Hatter replies that the hat is not his.
The King immediately concludes the hat must be "Stolen!" and directs the jury to record this, which they do instantly.
The Hatter clarifies that he is a hatter by trade and keeps hats for sale, possessing none of his own.
At this point, the Queen puts on her spectacles and begins to stare intently at the Hatter, making him turn pale and fidget nervously.
The King demands the Hatter give his evidence, warning him not to be nervous under threat of immediate execution.
This threat fails to calm the Hatter; he shifts anxiously from foot to foot, glancing worriedly at the Queen, and in his disarray, bites a chunk out of his teacup instead of his bread-and-butter.
Simultaneously, Alice becomes aware of a peculiar physical sensation and realizes she has begun to grow taller again; considering leaving, she ultimately decides to stay as long as space permits.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

events.text_segment:
“Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a great deal to come before that!”
“Call the first witness,” said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, “First witness!”
The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. “I beg pardon, your Majesty,” he began, “for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished my tea when I was sent for.”
“You ought to have finished,” said the King. “When did you begin?”
The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. “Fourteenth of March, I think it was,” he said.
“Fifteenth,” said the March Hare.
“Sixteenth,” added the Dormouse.
“Write that down,” the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
“Take off your hat,” the King said to the Hatter.
“It isn’t mine,” said the Hatter.
“Stolen!” the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.
“I keep them to sell,” the Hatter added as an explanation; “I’ve none of my own. I’m a hatter.”
Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.
“Give your evidence,” said the King; “and don’t be nervous, or I’ll have you executed on the spot.”
This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “A little more patience, please! I’m late, I tell you—late for an important date!” Alice watched him scurry along, his pocket watch swinging wildly from his paw. She wondered what could be so urgent that a rabbit would be in such a rush, yet she felt a strange curiosity stirring within her.

As she looked around, she noticed the garden was filled with peculiar sights: flowers that seemed to whisper secrets to each other, mushrooms that shimmered with an otherworldly glow, and trees that appeared to lean in, eager to listen. The White Rabbit, meanwhile, was now darting toward a small door set into a hedge, clutching his pocket watch tightly.

Alice, intrigued, stepped closer. The door was tiny—just her size—and she wondered how she could possibly get through. She looked around for a key but saw none. Suddenly, a curious caterpillar sitting atop a mushroom puffed smoke rings into the air and regarded her with half-lidded eyes.

“Excuse me,” Alice said politely, “but do you happen to have a key for that door?”

The caterpillar took a slow drag from his hookah and looked at her thoughtfully. “A key, you say? Perhaps. But first, tell me, who are you?”

“I’m Alice,” she replied, “and I’ve just arrived in this strange place. I was following the White Rabbit, and now I find myself quite lost.”

The caterpillar nodded slowly. “Lost, are you? Well, then, perhaps you need to grow a little—” he paused, “—or perhaps shrink a bit. The answer lies within the mushroom.”

Alice looked at the mushroom, pondering his words. She reached out and took a bite from one side, feeling a strange tingling sensation. Instantly, she felt herself grow taller, then smaller, as if the very fabric of her size was shifting.

With her new size, she approached the tiny door again, eager to see what lay beyond. The White Rabbit, still in a hurry, glanced back once more, muttering about being late. Alice, now small enough to fit through the door, took a deep breath and stepped inside, ready for whatever adventures awaited her in this curious land.

events.title: Alice's Growth Spurt Causes Conflict
detailed_summary: The Dormouse, positioned next to the rapidly growing Alice, complains about being squeezed and unable to breathe properly.
Alice responds meekly, stating she cannot control her growth.
The Dormouse counters that she has no entitlement to grow specifically within the confines of the court.
Alice dismisses this argument more assertively, pointing out that the Dormouse is also subject to growth.
The Dormouse insists its own growth occurs at a 'reasonable pace,' unlike Alice's 'ridiculous fashion'.
Visibly annoyed, the Dormouse gets up and moves to the other side of the courtroom.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.” said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.

events.text_segment:
“I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.” said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her. “I can hardly breathe.”
“I can’t help it,” said Alice very meekly: “I’m growing.”
“You’ve no right to grow here,” said the Dormouse.
“Don’t talk nonsense,” said Alice more boldly: “you know you’re growing too.”
“Yes, but I grow at a reasonable pace,” said the Dormouse: “not in that ridiculous fashion.” And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.

events.text_segment:
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!” on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.
“Give your evidence,” the King repeated angrily, “or I’ll have you executed, whether you’re nervous or not.”
“I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, “—and I hadn’t begun my tea—not above a week or so—and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin—and the twinkling of the tea—”
“The twinkling of the what?” said the King.
“It began with the tea,” the Hatter replied.
“Of course twinkling begins with a T!” said the King sharply. “Do you take me for a dunce? Go on!”
“I’m a poor man,” the Hatter went on, “and most things twinkled after that—only the March Hare said—”
“I didn’t!” the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.
“You did!” said the Hatter.
“I deny it!” said the March Hare.
“He denies it,” said the King: “leave out that part.”
“Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said—” the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.
“After that,” continued the Hatter, “I cut some more bread-and-butter—”
“But what did the Dormouse say?” one of the jury asked.
“That I can’t remember,” said the Hatter.
“You must remember,” remarked the King, “or I’ll have you executed.”
The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee. “I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” he began.
“You’re a very poor speaker,” said the King.
Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)
“I’m glad I’ve seen that done,” thought Alice. “I’ve so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials, “There was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court,” and I never understood what it meant till now.”
“If that’s all you know about it, you may stand down,” continued the King.
“I can’t go no lower,” said the Hatter: “I’m on the floor, as it is.”
“Then you may sit down,” the King replied.
Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
“Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!” thought Alice. “Now we shall get on better.”
“I’d rather finish my tea,” said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.
“You may go,” said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.
“—and just take his head off outside,” the Queen added to one of the officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!” on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.

The King, very angry, repeated his demand for evidence, and said he would have his head if he did not produce it. The Hatter, trembling and nervous, began to give a very shaky testimony.

"Poverty," he said, "and unfinished tea, and thin bread-and-butter, and the twinkling of the tea!" The King looked at him in surprise.

"What is this twinkling tea?" he asked. "I don't know," said the Hatter, "but most things twinkled, I believe."

"And what did the March Hare say?" asked the King.

"He said, 'Most things twinkled,'" replied the Hatter.

The March Hare immediately denied it, but the Hatter insisted, and the King ruled that part of the testimony should be disregarded.

Then the Hatter tried to quote the Dormouse, but he looked around nervously, and the Dormouse, who was fast asleep, made no reply.

"He said he was cutting more bread-and-butter," added the Hatter.

A juror asked what the Dormouse had said, and the Hatter admitted he could not remember.

"Then you must remember," said the King, "or you shall be executed!"

Overwhelmed, the Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and fell to one knee, begging for mercy.

"You are a very poor speaker," said the King, and the court officers, seeing the Hatter's distress, stuffed a guinea-pig into a canvas bag and sat on it to suppress it.

Alice, watching this, thought to herself that she now understood what 'suppression' meant.

The King then told the Hatter he might stand down, and the Hatter, still kneeling, said he could not go any lower.

"Then sit down," said the King.

The other guinea-pig cheered, and was also suppressed.

Alice thought the interruptions were over, and hoped they could now proceed.

The Hatter, eager to finish his tea, looked anxiously at the Queen, who was busy with the list of singers.

"You may go," said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left, forgetting his shoes.

The Queen then ordered an officer to behead the Hatter outside, but he had already vanished from sight.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The list was brought, and the Queen, after glancing over it, exclaimed, “What! No singing birds? No singing frogs? No singing mice?” Her voice was sharp and commanding, echoing through the court like a clap of thunder. The Hatter, trembling, tried to speak, but his words were lost in the tumult of the Queen’s fury. Alice watched with wide eyes, her curiosity piqued by the strange proceedings.

Suddenly, the Queen’s gaze fixed upon the Hatter again, and she declared, “Off with his head!” The court burst into chaos, with courtiers scrambling to obey or to plead for mercy. The Hatter, in a panic, bowed deeply, begging for his life and explaining that the list was merely a list of the songs they had sung, not of the singers themselves.

The Queen, however, was not to be appeased. “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!” she repeated, her voice ringing like a bell. The officers hurried away, returning shortly with a scroll that contained the names of various singers, all of whom had performed at the last concert.

As the list was read aloud, the Queen’s expression softened slightly, but her temper was still volatile. She pointed at a name and demanded, “Who is this?” The courtier responded, “That is the name of the frog who sang the bass.”

The Queen clapped her hands, delighted. “A singing frog! How charming!” she exclaimed. Then, turning to Alice, she said, “You see, my dear, in Wonderland, even the frogs have a voice. We must appreciate all the talents here, no matter how peculiar they may seem.”

Alice, feeling a mixture of amusement and confusion, nodded politely. She wondered what other strange sights and sounds awaited her in this curious court. The Dormouse, who had been quietly dozing, suddenly woke up and mumbled something about a tea party, but no one paid him much attention.

The court continued its bizarre proceedings, with the Queen occasionally demanding to see more lists, more names, and more singing creatures. Alice, meanwhile, pondered the oddity of it all, realizing that in Wonderland, the rules of logic and order were quite different from her world.

As the court finally adjourned, the Queen declared, “Off with the list!” and the scroll was rolled up and handed back to the officer. The Queen then turned her attention to Alice, giving her a piercing look. “And what do you think of our court, young lady?” she asked.

Alice hesitated, then replied, “It’s very curious, Your Majesty. But I think I’d rather be somewhere else.” The Queen chuckled, a sound like a crack of thunder, and said, “Perhaps you shall, soon enough. But for now, enjoy the spectacle!” And with that, the court dissolved into a flurry of chatter and laughter, leaving Alice to wonder what other wonders awaited her in Wonderland.

events.title: The Cook's Brief Appearance and the Dormouse's Ejection
detailed_summary: The King calls for the next witness.
The Duchess's cook enters, carrying her pepper-box.
Alice immediately recognizes her, partly because people near the entrance begin sneezing uncontrollably.
The King requests her evidence.
The cook bluntly refuses, stating, "Shan't."
The King looks uncertainly at the White Rabbit, who quietly advises that His Majesty must cross-examine this witness.
Resignedly, the King accepts, folds his arms, frowns deeply at the cook, and asks in a solemn voice what tarts are composed of.
The cook replies, "Pepper, mostly."

events.text_segment:
“Call the next witness!” said the King.
The next witness was the Duchess’s cook. She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
“Give your evidence,” said the King.
“Shan’t,” said the cook.
The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice, “Your Majesty must cross-examine this witness.”
“Well, if I must, I must,” the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, “What are tarts made of?”
“Pepper, mostly,” said the cook.
“Treacle,” said a sleepy voice behind her.
“Collar that Dormouse,” the Queen shrieked out. “Behead that Dormouse! Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his whiskers!”
For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.
“Never mind!” said the King, with an air of great relief. “Call the next witness.”

events.title: Alice Disrupts the Court and Upsets the Jury
detailed_summary: Forgetting her recent growth spurt in the heat of the moment, Alice jumps up and accidentally knocks over the jury box with her skirt.
The jurymen tumble out onto the crowd below, reminding Alice of goldfish she once spilled.
Feeling dismayed, Alice quickly starts picking up the jurymen, worried they might perish if not returned to the box immediately, like the goldfish.
The King solemnly declares the trial cannot continue until every juryman is back in their correct place, emphasizing the point while looking pointedly at Alice.
Alice notices she put the Lizard back upside down in her haste; it waves its tail helplessly.
She rights the Lizard, though she privately muses that its orientation likely makes no difference to its usefulness in the trial.
Once the jury recovers and gets their slates and pencils back, they diligently begin writing an account of the disruption.
The Lizard, however, seems too stunned to do anything but sit with its mouth open, staring at the ceiling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.

events.text_segment:
“Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
“Oh, I beg your pardon!” she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.
“The trial cannot proceed,” said the King in a very grave voice, “until all the jurymen are back in their proper places—all,” he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said so.
Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got it out again, and put it right; “not that it signifies much,” she said to herself; “I should think it would be quite as much use in the trial one way up as the other.”
As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.

The King frowned and looked at her sternly. “The trial cannot go on till all the jurymen are back in their proper places,” he said, pointing his finger at her. Alice hurriedly began picking up the jurymen, worried they might perish if not returned to the box immediately, just as she had once spilled a bowl of goldfish.

She noticed she had put the Lizard back upside down in her haste; it waved its tail helplessly. She righted it, though she privately mused that its orientation probably made no difference to its usefulness in the trial.

events.text_segment:
“What do you know about this business?” the King said to Alice.
“Nothing,” said Alice.
“Nothing whatever?” persisted the King.
“Nothing whatever,” said Alice.
“That’s very important,” the King said, turning to the jury. They were just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit interrupted: “Unimportant, your Majesty means, of course,” he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.
“Unimportant, of course, I meant,” the King hastily said, and went on to himself in an undertone,
“important—unimportant—unimportant—important—” as if he were trying which word sounded best.
Some of the jury wrote it down “important,” and some “unimportant.” Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates; “but it doesn’t matter a bit,” she thought to herself.

events.title: Rule Forty-Two and Alice's Logical Defiance
detailed_summary: The King, after writing in his notebook, shouts for silence and reads "Rule Forty-two": anyone over a mile high must leave court.
All eyes turn to Alice.
Alice protests that she is not a mile high.
The King contradicts her, and the Queen adds that Alice is nearly two miles high.
Alice firmly states she won't leave, asserting the rule is irregular and just invented by the King.
The King claims it's the oldest rule in the book.
Alice retorts that, if true, it should logically be Rule Number One.
Visibly flustered, the King turns pale, snaps his notebook shut, and nervously tells the jury to consider their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out “Silence!” and read out from his book, “Rule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. “Consider your verdict,” he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

events.text_segment:
At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out “Silence!” and read out from his book, “Rule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court.”
Everybody looked at Alice.
“I’m not a mile high,” said Alice.
“You are,” said the King.
“Nearly two miles high,” added the Queen.
“Well, I shan’t go, at any rate,” said Alice: “besides, that’s not a regular rule: you invented it just now.”
“It’s the oldest rule in the book,” said the King.
“Then it ought to be Number One,” said Alice.
The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. “Consider your verdict,” he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

events.title: Mysterious Unsigned Verses Presented as Evidence
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit hastily interrupts, announcing new evidence in the form of a recently found paper.
The Queen inquires about its contents.
The Rabbit explains it appears to be a letter from the prisoner to someone, but he hasn't opened it yet.
The King speculates it must be addressed to someone, unless, unusually, it was written to nobody.
A juryman asks who it is addressed to.
The Rabbit reveals it has no address and nothing written on the outside.
He unfolds the paper and clarifies it's not a letter but a set of verses.
Another juryman asks if the verses are in the prisoner's handwriting.
The Rabbit replies that they are not, which he finds very peculiar, baffling the jury.
The King suggests the prisoner must have imitated someone else's handwriting, which seems to satisfy the jury.
The Knave speaks up, denying he wrote it and stating they cannot prove he did, as there is no signature.
The King illogically argues that not signing makes matters worse, implying mischievous intent, a statement met with applause as his first clever remark.
The Queen declares the Knave's guilt proven by this.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That proves his guilt,” said the Queen.

events.text_segment:
“There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”
“What’s in it?” said the Queen.
“I haven’t opened it yet,” said the White Rabbit, “but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to—to somebody.”
“It must have been that,” said the King, “unless it was written to nobody, which isn’t usual, you know.”
“Who is it directed to?” said one of the jurymen.
“It isn’t directed at all,” said the White Rabbit; “in fact, there’s nothing written on the outside.” He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added “It isn’t a letter, after all: it’s a set of verses.”
“Are they in the prisoner’s handwriting?” asked another of the jurymen.
“No, they’re not,” said the White Rabbit, “and that’s the queerest thing about it.” (The jury all looked puzzled.)
“He must have imitated somebody else’s hand,” said the King. (The jury all brightened up again.)
“Please your Majesty,” said the Knave, “I didn’t write it, and they can’t prove I did: there’s no name signed at the end.”
“If you didn’t sign it,” said the King, “that only makes the matter worse. You must have meant some mischief, or else you’d have signed your name like an honest man.”
There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.
“That proves his guilt,” said the Queen.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”

The Queen looked at the White Rabbit as he came hurriedly into the court, and said, “That’s the second time you’ve rushed in like that.”

The White Rabbit put on his spectacles and looked at the paper. “It’s a letter from the prisoner,” he said, “and I haven’t read it yet.”

The Queen asked, “What does it say?”

The White Rabbit explained, “It appears to be a letter addressed to someone, but I haven’t opened it.”

The King said, “It must be addressed to someone, unless it’s written to nobody, which is very unlikely.”

A juryman asked, “Who is it addressed to?”

The White Rabbit replied, “It has no address, and nothing written on the outside.”

He unfolded the paper and said, “It’s not a letter, but a set of verses.”

Another juryman asked, “Are the verses in the prisoner’s handwriting?”

The White Rabbit answered, “No, they are not, which I find very strange, and it’s puzzling the jury.”

The King suggested, “The prisoner must have imitated someone else’s handwriting,” which seemed to satisfy the jury.

The Knave then spoke up, denying he wrote it, and said, “We cannot prove I did, as there is no signature.”

The King, in an illogical manner, said, “Not signing makes it worse, implying mischievous intent,” and this was met with applause as his first clever remark.

The Queen declared, “The Knave’s guilt is proven by this.”

The King, in an illogical manner, said, “Not signing makes it worse, implying mischievous intent,” and this was met with applause as his first clever remark.

The Queen declared, “The Knave’s guilt is proven by this.”

The White Rabbit looked anxiously at the Queen. "Shall I fetch the Mad Hatter? Perhaps he can help decipher this." The Queen nodded impatiently. "Yes, do that at once! We cannot afford any delays. The Queen of Hearts is not known for her patience, after all." As the White Rabbit hurried away, the court buzzed with anticipation, eager to uncover the mystery behind the strange paper.

detailed_summary: Alice interjects, stating the verses prove nothing as their meaning is unknown.
The King instructs the White Rabbit to read the verses.
The Rabbit puts on spectacles and asks where to start.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Let the jury consider their verdict,” the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.

events.text_segment:
“It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”
“Read them,” said the King.
The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. “Where shall I begin, please your Majesty?” he asked.
“Begin at the beginning,” the King said gravely, “and go on till you come to the end: then stop.”
These were the verses the White Rabbit read:—
“They told me you had been to her,
    And mentioned me to him:
She gave me a good character,
    But said I could not swim.

He sent them word I had not gone
    (We know it to be true):
If she should push the matter on,
    What would become of you?

I gave her one, they gave him two,
    You gave us three or more;
They all returned from him to you,
    Though they were mine before.

If I or she should chance to be
    Involved in this affair,
He trusts to you to set them free,
    Exactly as we were.

My notion was that you had been
    (Before she had this fit)
An obstacle that came between
    Him, and ourselves, and it.

Don’t let him know she liked them best,
    For this must ever be
A secret, kept from all the rest,
    Between yourself and me.”
“That’s the most important piece of evidence we’ve heard yet,” said the King, rubbing his hands; “so now let the jury—”
“If any one of them can explain it,” said Alice, (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn’t a bit afraid of interrupting him,) “I’ll give him sixpence. I don’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it.”
The jury all wrote down on their slates, “She doesn’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it,” but none of them attempted to explain the paper.
“If there’s no meaning in it,” said the King, “that saves a world of trouble, you know, as we needn’t try to find any. And yet I don’t know,” he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; “I seem to see some meaning in them, after all. “—said I could not swim—” you can’t swim, can you?” he added, turning to the Knave.
The Knave shook his head sadly. “Do I look like it?” he said. (Which he certainly did not, being made entirely of cardboard.)
“All right, so far,” said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: “‘We know it to be true—’ that’s the jury, of course—‘I gave her one, they gave him two—’ why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know—”
“But, it goes on ‘they all returned from him to you,’” said Alice.
“Why, there they are!” said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts on the table. “Nothing can be clearer than that. Then again—‘before she had this fit—’ you never had fits, my dear, I think?” he said to the Queen.
“Never!” said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)
“Then the words don’t fit you,” said the King, looking round the court with a smile. There was a dead silence.
“It’s a pun!” the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed, “Let the jury consider their verdict,” the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"It proves nothing of the sort!" said Alice. "Why, you don't even know what they're about!" The King looked at the White Rabbit, who was now adjusting his spectacles nervously.

"Read the verses," the King commanded gravely.

The White Rabbit took a deep breath, put on his spectacles, and asked, "Where shall I begin?"

"Begin at the beginning," the King said, "and go on till you come to the end; then stop."

The Rabbit cleared his throat and began to read:

"Pronouns swimming in the sea,
Gifts and secrets, what could they be?
Give me tarts, or give me none,
The answer's hidden, but it's not gone."

The King declared, "This is the most important evidence yet," and prepared to instruct the jury.

Alice, now larger and more confident, called out, "If anyone can explain that poem, I’ll give them a shilling! I think it’s all nonsense."

The jury members scribbled notes, but made no attempt to interpret the verses.

The King mused, "Perhaps if it’s meaningless, it simplifies things," but then he tried to make sense of it.

"The line about not swimming," he said, "must refer to the Knave."

"Yes," said the Knave, "I can't swim."

"And the line about giving tarts," the King continued, "must relate to the Queen, who loves her tarts."

"But," Alice pointed out, "there's a line about items being returned."

The King looked puzzled, then linked the line about a 'fit' to the Queen, who suddenly looked furious.

"I have no fits!" she exclaimed, and in her anger, threw her inkstand at the Lizard.

The Lizard began writing with the spilled ink.

"The words about fits don't suit the Queen," the King said, "and the pun on 'fit' is quite amusing."

Everyone laughed at the joke, and the King repeated, "Now, consider your verdict carefully."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The Queen of Hearts, who had been watching the exchange with a frown, now stamped her foot impatiently. "Off with her head!" she shouted, her voice echoing through the garden. Alice looked around, bewildered by the sudden turn of events. "But I haven't done anything!" she exclaimed, trying to reason with the Queen. "You must be mad!" The King of Hearts, who had been quietly observing, cleared his throat and said, "Now, now, let's not be hasty. Perhaps we should hear what Alice has to say." Alice nodded gratefully, turning to the Queen. "Please, Your Majesty, I was only trying to understand the rules of this strange game. I didn't mean any harm." The Queen's eyes narrowed, but she seemed to consider Alice's words. "Very well," she said gruffly. "But if you step out of line again, you'll be in trouble." Alice felt a wave of relief wash over her. She looked around at the curious crowd gathered in the garden, all eager to see what would happen next. The Cheshire Cat, perched lazily on a nearby branch, grinned widely. "You see," he said, "nothing in Wonderland is quite what it seems. You must learn to think differently here." Alice nodded, pondering his words. She realized that in this strange land, the rules were fluid, and understanding came from embracing the absurd. As she continued to explore, she encountered the Mad Hatter, who was busy pouring tea into a teacup that was already overflowing. "Would you care for some tea?" he asked cheerfully. Alice accepted, sitting down at the cluttered table. "Tell me," she said, "what is the meaning of all this?" The Mad Hatter chuckled. "Meaning? Oh, we don't bother with that here. We just enjoy the moment." Alice sipped her tea, feeling a strange sense of calm despite the chaos around her. Suddenly, the White Rabbit hurried past, looking frantic. "Oh dear! Oh dear!" he exclaimed. "I'm late!" Alice watched him scurry away, then turned to the Cheshire Cat. "Where am I supposed to go from here?" she asked. The Cat grinned again. "Follow the White Rabbit. He always knows where he's going, even if he doesn't know himself." Alice decided to follow the White Rabbit, her curiosity piqued. She hurried after him, weaving through the crowd of peculiar creatures and talking flowers. As she ran, she thought about the strange conversations she'd had and the odd rules of this land. She remembered the Queen's angry outburst and wondered if she would ever find her way back home. The White Rabbit led her to a grand door with a golden handle. "This is it," he said breathlessly. "You must go through this door to find the Queen of Hearts." Alice hesitated, then reached out and turned the handle. The door swung open to reveal a vast, colorful garden filled with playing cards and singing flowers. At the center sat the Queen of Hearts, who looked up and smiled kindly. "Welcome, Alice," she said softly. "We've been expecting you." Alice stepped inside, feeling both nervous and excited. She knew that in Wonderland, anything was possible, and she was ready to face whatever came next. As she approached the Queen, she realized that her adventure was only just beginning.

events.title: Sentence Before Verdict and Alice's Final Rebellion
detailed_summary: The Queen interrupts the King's call for a verdict, demanding the sentence be given first.
Alice loudly protests this idea as illogical nonsense.
The Queen, turning purple with anger, orders Alice to be silent.
Alice defiantly refuses.
The Queen shrieks for Alice's execution.
Nobody in the court makes a move to carry out the order.
Alice, having reached her full height, dismisses the Queen and the entire court.
She declares that she doesn't care about them because they are nothing more than a pack of cards.

events.text_segment:
“No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first—verdict afterwards.”
“Stuff and nonsense!” said Alice loudly. “The idea of having the sentence first!”
“Hold your tongue!” said the Queen, turning purple.
“I won’t!” said Alice.
“Off with her head!” the Queen shouted at the top of her voice. Nobody moved.
“Who cares for you?” said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.) “You’re nothing but a pack of cards!”
